It's neat.

The small spherical planets and the resulting inability to have a flat surface for building bases frustrates me to no end. To make matters worse, the mining tool absolutely ruins the natural terrain and there's no good way to fix it. Five minutes into a new save and the starter planet is already riddled with potholes. Platforms are strewn all over the place at odd angles because we can't have flat ground or foundations to build on. It's just so frustrating.

The storage system is unique and honestly pretty cool, except for the fact that it is wholly inadequate. Eight slots on a "medium" storage unit is less than what we can fit in our backpacks, so the base ends up being more than half storage.

Exploration in the early game is a matter of making and placing tethers all over the planet. Tethers which will end up falling over due to mining and attempts at fixing holes, or which can be just knocked over accidentally by players walking around.

In the best way, it is a buggy mess.
A really loveable buggy mess.

Astroneer is an absolute gem of an adventure game that has captured my heart. It offers a rich tapestry of game-play experiences where you can build intricate bases, embark on thrilling explorations across diverse landscapes, and delve into mysterious caves teeming with secrets. The freedom to unlock, fabricate, and cruise around in various vehicles adds an extra layer of excitement to the journey.

One of the most enticing features of Astroneer is its boundless sense of exploration. If the starting planet doesn't quite tickle your fancy, fear not! You have the freedom to pack up your belongings and venture forth to new worlds, each with its own unique wonders waiting to be uncovered.

With its seamless integration of multiplayer, Astroneer becomes an even more delightful experience when shared with friends. Whether you're embarking on daring expeditions together or simply basking in the joy of crafting and storytelling, the game offers endless possibilities for collaborative fun.

In summary, Astroneer is a masterpiece for anyone who relishes the thrill of discovery, the joy of camaraderie, or simply seeks an immersive narrative experience. With its captivating game-play and boundless potential, it easily earns a perfect score of 10/10 in my book.

this is an amazing adventure game that i love. you can build a base, explore around the world or go to the caves. you can also unlock, print, and drive cars/rovers. and if you dont like the starting planet you can always pack up all your stuff and move to another one. 10/10 game for anyone who likes to explore, discover new areas with friends or just looking for a fun story game (with friends)

A hesitant "not recommended" as there is no real neutral option, but my points sway towards negative. 

The game is very cute. I love the lil character models and the poly style graphics. I played this several years ago and wondered today why I had stopped playing. Now I remember why.

This game gives me some very heavy motion sickness. The player camera goes all over the place and it's very hard to control. I'm now taking anti-nausea medicine after playing for only half an hour. It's also lacking in any kind of starting tutorial, so it's really quite confusing trying to figure out what everything is, how to access things, and what you're supposed to do. 

I really do want to love this game, but the motion sickness is honestly so bad for me.
veri gud.
149 hours... where did the time go!!
I like how good it is (very good). Good job!

Core concepts are solid and I loved it in EA, but it hasn't gotten that much better. 

Exploring gets boring pretty quickly. Planets are all ascetically different and have different resources, but much of the same. Hazards are trivial being that all of them can be defeated by taking a few steps back and digging them up. Storms were a key motivator for choosing a good base location as well as giving a challenge in exploring, and I will never understand why they were removed with no option to reenable. 

Speaking of base building, coming from other games it feels very limited and clunky. No platforms or structures to build on or grid to snap to, and is overall very 2D for a 3D game. It makes the manufacturing chains tedious.

Speaking of automation, IMO it is very basic. Each step is 1-2 inputs, 1 output, and rates aren't important or even mentioned. It's very accessible but difficulty could scale at least a little. Seasoned factory enthusiasts will be disappointed. Even the automation you set up, since you build at such a relatively small scale, is only good for building more automation or just duplicating your base on another planet. You never have a use for massive quantities of items for anything other than goofing around with friends, blowing stuff up, or messing with rovers, but to be honest there are more fun games to do that in.

As far as exploration goes, finding research becomes a chore once you know where to look, and after grinding through it, there isn't that much of an incentive to do it anymore. The small points of interest like capsules and debris never really give anything worth your time. Although did like the addition of the snails and the later lore missions. IMO they are one of the more fun sets of missions and did get me having fun and exploring again. They also made seed automation useful. But activating all of the gateways for the ending is grindy and not really worth your time. The teleporters they give just aren't that convenient.

Microtransactions were slapped on to make some extra dough, which I'm never a fan of, but at least cosmetics are the only things paywalled. The FOMO from limited time events is annoying, and they are much better suited to be a toggleable gamemode. Modding is against the EULA (my only guess is out of fear of bypassing MTX) which is a shame because this game needs it desperately.

TLDR It's unique and still a decent time waster, but just play Space Engineers. It's a learning curve but has leagues more play time, infinitely larger modding community, PvP, complex automation, and is $10 cheaper. It's a no-brainer.

This game is so much fun that I've 100%'d it multiple times. It's a great game that offers a [u]unique[/u] and [u]engaging[/u] experience for players. Its gameplay mechanics are a great blend of survival, exploration, and crafting that are quick to pick up and are a fun gameplay loop. The game's terraforming system adds a level of creativity and experimentation to the gameplay too. Its stunning visuals, with a beautiful, cartoonish art style, are a great addition when exploring new planets. And, the color palette is so vibrant and varied, with each planet having its unique terrain and environmental features.  Also, the relaxing and ambient soundtrack perfectly complements the game's visuals, which creates an immersive experience for players. Furthermore, the sound effects are well-designed and add to the game's overall atmosphere, making players feel like they are really exploring an alien world.

Astroneer's attention to detail is impressive, with intricate designs and realistic physics adding to the game's overall sense of realism. The way the UI is handled like inventory and crafting is such a unique way of displaying it all too. There is always something new to discover, whether it's a new resource, new machine, or new challenge to overcome. Astroneer is a [b]great game[/b] that offers a unique and engaging experience in the open world survival genre. Its blend of gameplay mechanics, beautiful visuals, relaxing soundtrack, attention to detail, and great support from the devs make it a must-play for anyone who enjoys survival, exploration, and coop games.

I would describe it as "good game if you don't play it too much", which is... not something I can happily recommend.

Controls are functional, but:
When dragging objects or the camera, there is significant smoothing that makes things lag far behind the mouse and frequently not reach the intended location before you try using them.
All UIs and interfaces are physical objects than can and will clip through and over each other and the player character.
Some things are bound to the same keys and cannot be altered, e.g. scrolling through items to craft in the backpack is either physical buttons or the arrow keys, and the arrow keys are also secondary walking controls, meaning you have to WASD in the other direction at the same time to avoid falling off ledges.
When mining (with the mouse), you are still able to click on and open the backpack (and everything attached to it) in a third person game where the camera will often be directly behind it.

Technical issues can be serious:
On some PCs the uncapped framerate in the main menu will crash the game (and sometimes your PC) which can be fixed from the outside using a settings .ini file.
There is a bug known (to the community AND devs) that means an objective vital to an entire mission progression branch does not spawn in your save, meaning it simply cannot be 100% completed - not to mention it's the mission(s) that leads to the best mobility unlock in the game. It can only be fixed by someone with the capability to edit saves, i.e. the only 'fix' for the average person is literally sending the save file to a dev. This has existed for years, even after a supposed fix was added. I have had it happen twice, the second time being exasperating enough for me to finally update my review.
Updates are primarily to add limited time events or new (paid) cosmetics.

I really would like to review this positively, however the big issue with the game is lack of a driving force. This issue is apparent from the very beginning, although it starts out much smaller of an issue, it grows to be a massive hindrance to the enjoyment of the game. The missions are fairly pointless, and nothing more than a checkbox, even the rewards are boring. Oh another qt-rtg... neat, add it to the pile (no pun intended).

After our playthrough, we only felt it needed to make bases on 4 planets total, and the 3 aux bases are quite small and very utilitarian. Pretty much every unique thing we found, ended up being just research or something to throw in the shredder. The game sort of dabbles in automation with its grabbers and trains, but for what reason, there is none. Its pretty sad that such a good foundation of a game, can be stuffed with the same stuff, and end up feeling so empty, for example, if you travel down into caves, such as the mantle, you have 9999 capsules for event drops, why... its so littered with them that its hard to navigate through the caves. Oh and the "mysteries of the solar system", yeah its... [spoiler]teleporters. Everything we did, we was so underwhelmed we didn't even desire to finish activating the cores, so I looked it up and after activating all the cores, what do you get? A cutscene and credits. So glad I didn't.[/spoiler]

All-in-all, this feels like an early access title, although its not. So disappointing.

Astroneer is a very fun game where you play as an astronaut who explores different planets in an attempt to research, discover, and find out all the secrets that each planet and moon hold.

To start, there isn't really any story to the game. There are things called "curiosities" and other items that hold pieces of lore, but they are something that you can ignore entirely. The main appeal to this game is its gameplay, now i think this is something we can relate to in real life. We aren't told what to do and we have to figure it out ourselves.

This game is really fun with friends and not so much alone. This is what we are doing in our government. They have control over us and we can't do anything about it. We will crumble and that's the sad truth.

The graphics are also very attractive, just like the government tries to make the military attractive. They want you to be their slaves, don't give in. This is corruption in our government. They are lying to you about everything and all of this is represented in Astroneer. We need to get this game out there so people can understand the truth. The aliens are real, they are lying. 

All in all, its a really fun game and I think you should try it!

Interesting game. In some aspects like a more detailed minecraft with interstellar travel. But ultimately, I don't think there is enough content here. 

The real killer is the bugs. Tonnes of bugs. You can go to certain places and just inexplicably die. My friend's backpack simply wouldn't charge and would fit out all the time. many people mention it online, and the only fix was to restart the game, but that didn't work here. He'd have no energy but for some reason his portable O2 tank would still work. There are parts of the game designed to make you fail and have to recover a lot of resources. Effectively, a weak design way of extending the game. Others that you can only succeed in, if you turn to google. 

It's an interesting game, but I wouldn't recommend it unless you have cash to burn and don't mind a lot of frustration and bad game design.

There are some bugs, nothing that is a show stopper, but definitely stuff I notice that is annoying. Best example: Multiple times I have created flat ground to start building a base and when I set something down on the ground, it somehow floats through and then disappears! I've lost buggies through the ground, the folding trays loaded with materials through the ground, etc. It doesn't happen often and I've learned to never set anything I care about on the ground that I created by making the area flat because I can't trust it'll stay there lol. The camera is a little funky in the way that if you pan around and it zooms in because of an obstacle behind the camera, it never zooms back out again so I feel like I'm constantly scrolling down to pull the camera view back out to where I had it before. Overall, a super fun game, I enjoy the solo play with no creatures, no real big shenanigans, it doesn't take much brain power to play, and it really scratches some kind of organizational itch or something for me. 276 hours of game time as of this review.

The game has 5 planets and 2 moons to explore, each being different from one another. The environment is colorful and vast with a calming soundtrack.
Your only enemies in this game are oxygen, fall damage aaaannd.... plants? Seriously, don't underestimate them.

If you're interested in a space theme and are looking for something laid back then I'd strongly recommend this game. It's a beautiful journey to be on.

Any new player could get over 100 hours of playtime, easily. Beyond that though, there isn't much to the game besides the progression system. Don't get me wrong, Astroneer's progression is by far the best of any game I've seen, but once you've got every resource, and practically unlimited power there's not much more you can do. I've replayed this game 5 times now, and it's fun but it does get boring after 300 hours. The game is just too easy, there's no force pushing you back so you're almost guaranteed to to beat it. Sadly, I believe this is due to updates. Before 1.0 there were sandstorms that could kill you if you got caught them and didn't find/make shelter, which have now been removed. You can get unlimited oxygen by just sacrificing 2 slots on your backpack. Tethers would still be useful to not get lost, but then they added a compass to always tell you where you are. There aren't any moving enemys in the game (like zombies, or aliens) which I do support, however the lack of almost any challenge besides fall damage (which can be countered by a jet pack) is too much of a weakness for the game. I'm not some hardcore gamer either, I play Minecraft bedrock for crying out loud! 

So couldn't it just be a creative game that's not about surviving? Maybe, but the game wasn't made for this, and you are almost forced to play along with the progression system, even after you've beaten it (it's weird) 
There is a creative mode, but it is only good until you've made the best rover, and crashed the game every way you can think of. Almost no one builds in creative mode like you would in Minecraft do to how infuriating the transforming system is. 

Back when I enjoyed this game, I described it as "Minecraft, in space, on steroids". Boy did the steroids wear off quick.
This game never ends. It is hard to get the hang of, but once you do, oh boy it's fun. (Tip:If you're bored, check the quest log for something to do._

9.5/10     Not going to lie it takes a few hours to get into the swing of things if you go into this game knowing nothing about it like I did, however after figuring out all the basics this game really is a fun experience. It's all about exploring, mining, and crafting in a way that feels fresh and well balanced compared to others in this sort of genre. The only con I saw to this game was the amount of looking up I had to do on wikis to understand some mechanics and functions of the game. Could just be a me thing too lol. Either way, I'd highly recommend this game for a fun and chill experience.

In a world where every survival exploration game tries to re-invent the wheel and you are hunted by monsters or zombies or weather that will literally kill you, Astroneer stood out as a game where I can pop on, relax, and enjoy some calming and sometimes hilarious exploration and base-building. With the addition of quests and structure, some guidance in the natural game progression can be helpful, but not overbearing. Lastly, the amount of content that the devs continue to roll out, holidays and special events make the game feel more alive. Highly recommend.

The first glitch that happened was one of our large storages clipping through the ground while we were away from it. We never found it. Next, occasionally when drilling, if I release the mouse button it just keeps digging for several seconds, making it impossible to reliably dig in a tight spot. Next, I'd jump and then freeze in mid-air. After a few seconds I would slam back down to the ground and die from fall damage. Next I couldn't walk at all (even after relogging) and had to wait for my friend to get past the oxygen tethers i was near so i could disconnect them and force a death (because I didn't want to respawn at the home world). The rover frequently gets stuck and you have to get out and dig under it to get it going again - this makes sense in some situations but most of the time it's just sitting on flat ground. The gravity flips near the core are not fun and the camera is pretty awful even before the majority of the bugs start happening.

Astroneer is peak relaxing game-play. In Astroneer there is no need to be pressured to progress or do work its all up to you. When you harvest resources they freely flow into your inventory with a distinct auditory signal for each type of resource. Everything in this game has a tactile element to it there are no 1 dimensional menus no png resources on a 1D inventory everything feels as if you could touch and interact with the objects you interact with. The soundtrack is very simple and relaxing as well as the visuals of each individual planet.  The voxel artstyle is very intuitive making the game appear more friendly. This is how Astroneer achieves the best relaxation experience.

This game is a great sandbox space exploration adventure! The sandbox element is not necessarily building "houses" but rather building functional bases full of machinery that helps you expand further. You explore the wilderness and caves for research items to unlock new base building items. You also explore for materials that you can use to print these base building items as well as vehicles, mobility items, and space shuttles!

Overall this game is great to play, and even more fun to play with friends! There is a slight learning curve, but there is an "Astropedia" built into the game that tells you what planets to get certain resources and gases to continue your crafting adventure!

Platinum Review

Astroneer is an amazing game with a unique set of modular base building that's intuitive, but allows for longer term complex automation. However, I don't feel this game adequately respects your time. Sylva, the first world, is amazing. It's exciting to explore, looking for new resources, salvaging from wrecks, disarming the dangerous fauna, and unpacking the mysterious gateway portals. Soon you run into the issue of new resources that cannot be found on Sylva, so, following the helpful quest guide, you set out among the stars, venturing to new planets... that have mostly the same resources, similar dangerous plants, and wrecks that sometimes have slightly different stuff than the wrecks on your first planet. 

At the core of each planet is possibly the most beautiful structure I've ever seen in a video game. The power generation and management, 3D printers, and soil centrifuge are all awesome mechanics. However, I think this game would be better if it was just one world. Needing to set up a separate base on most or all of the planets is a huge time consumer that has you doing the same thing over and over. Once you complete the first planet, you travel to all of the other planets and do the exact same thing. It doesn't add anything new to the game. 

The quests for starting out do a great job at guiding you through the beginning of the game. However, I don't feel the other main questlines: train depo, galastropods, and little prince, really add anything to the game. They often just deal with some clunky building through caves in glorified fetch quests across different planets. The trains are cool, but I don't really have any need to set up a dedicated travel system between points on a planet, I have a rover for that. The galastropods are cute, and have some unique functionality. Their quest is okay, it just pads runtime. At the very least, your little sister will probably love them, as mine does. 

My favorite part of this game is the custom start and world modifiers. Once you've played through the game, trying to play the start without a starting base is a totally unique experience. Going from having nothing to getting an oxygenator takes about 15-30 minutes and it is a desperate scramble to find the resources you need to progress while maintaining your ever-dwindling supply of oxygen packs. After you get the oxygenator, it's largely the same game other than not being able to get any quests because you need a starting base without an oxygenator (all fabricated bases will already have one). I wish that pre-req was removed because it's weird how it can stunt your non-traditional runs. 

Overall, I think this is a great game and I love it's base-building and finding new resources. However, I think you could play the game for 10ish hours, fly to other planets and grab their resources, and complete Sylva, and have seen all that this game has to offer. I don't think it is worth it for 30$, but reasonable for 15-20.

I tend to enjoy survival crafting games like this one! Unfortunately, this game is boring and tedious to play. I only made it through because I was playing with a friend, who also only made it through because he was playing with me. The controls and camera are clunky and difficult to use, and also make up the biggest challenge of the game, which provides little other challenge in terms of survival, resource management, combat, problem solving, or really anything else that one might expect out of the game. Exploration makes up a considerable chunk of the game, but it mostly consists of climbing up and down cliffs in a barren landscape. After the first few hours, I had seen pretty much all there was to discover beyond new color palettes and differently shaped resource deposits. While there is a story that is moderately compelling, it doesn't unlock until you've played through most of the game - for me, about 50 hours in - and the gameplay associated with that story quest, like most other quests, consists of carrying items from point A to point B and following markers on the compass. The thing is, this game does have some interesting sandbox potential, providing an assortment of tech which you can fit together to do surprising things, but the game doesn't incentivize you to play with it almost at all, outside of a couple of achievements. And the galastropods are cute - I'm quite fond of them. Regardless, there are simply better games out there that execute what this game tries to do in more interesting and engaging ways.

This game is really fun, I've played a lot of it for hours on end because I never get bored of it. Anyhow, more people should play this game, especially if they like open world games that are on the more chill side of games.

Astroneer is an open-world crafting game where you play as an astroneer (astronaut + engineer) who explores various planets in an attempt to research, discover, and find out all the secrets that each planet and moon hold. 

To start, there isn't really any story to the game. There are things called "curiosities" and other items that hold pieces of lore, but they are something that you can ignore entirely. The main appeal to this game is its gameplay, not the tiny bit of lore that can be found here and there.

As for the gameplay, it's pretty good. However, one major issue I need to talk about before I gush about the gameplay is that the start of your first playthrough is absolutely miserable for the first hour or two. The game has a horrible way of explaining what to do, how to control certain things, and more. The controls feel absolutely clunky, and you will struggle to do a lot of basic tasks. My friend and I genuinely disliked the game at first due to its inability to show the player how to properly do things, so you pretty much need to discover most of what the game has to offer via trial and error or just looking it up (which we did for a lot of things). There is also a mission system present in the game, but that didn't really help us much, either. There is just so much going on in the game that it acts as information overload.

Thankfully, once you get over that learning curve, the game starts to become really enjoyable. There are plenty of things to build, discover, and experiment with. The availability of resources makes it so you need to explore pretty much every planet and moon, allowing you to experience all the different planets that Astroneer has to offer. While some may think this leads to an exhausting grind, I feel like this allows for you to enjoy what a planet has to offer, and then once a planet/moon starts getting boring, you're able to go to the next planet/moon for a whole new environment. I also like how building automatic machines isn't a necessity. This isn't an automation game, but it certainly has the functions to turn it into one if you would like to. 

Also, while playing this game in single-player could certainly be enjoyable, I believe the best way to play this game is in multiplayer. Things like dividing tasks and exploring different areas make the game significantly less grindy and more enjoyable, as doing things with a good friend is always nice. 

The graphics are also very attractive, as the poly-style graphics are fully embraced and are an aspect of basically everything in the game. The sound design is also wonderful, as sounds like placing items onto storage platforms are very crisp. The background music doesn't really stand out much, but it adds a nice touch to the atmosphere, especially deep within cave layers. 

All in all, Astroneer is a rough gem that is clunky in some areas, but overall, it is a pleasure to play. While I wouldn't really want to play this by myself, I found the game to be quite enjoyable with my friend, and I recommend giving this game a try :)

Fair Warning: I only played this game for half an hour before refunding the game. I got it at 66% off.

I disliked this game because in the very short time I played, the controller support felt abysmal. Sometimes I would be looking at one object, try to grab it, and somehow grab an object off-camera, behind me, on the other side of my base, requiring me to walk all the way around to put it back before repeating the process.

Visual bugs were not fun to watch. Objects clip through eachother like mad.

The exploration seemed enjoyable enough, but the progression of the game is an increasingly complex linear set of fetch quests.

This would be okay if the fun exploration and the grind were accompanied by a story...  but there is none.

At least with games like Factorio, the endless grind is addicting because its's a reward loop of fixing one problem which reveals more and more problems, until you say screw it and scrap your old factory in hopes of creating a much larger and more capable one. This game is just... the first half hour of Minecraft on repeat.

7/10! Fun enough but not for $10... certainly not for $30.

I guess i have to change my last review to some degree, the old one looked like that:


"Played it, was under immersersed under incentivied, put it to shelv. Came back was immersed and incintivised played the plot and felt a gaping whole, thought i could fill it with mp. found out mp is riddled with griefers. new update hit: basic core gameplay destroyed through devs decision to implement a "rare" resource (exo chips) and forced it into existing build reciepes.
 No don't play it. the devs seem to have no idea to make the game more fun with the game with new updates and destroy old fun playstyles.
play some other sandbox. play space engineers, play minecraft, play empyrion.

AVOID this game at least until the changes of this patch have been undone.
Unfun.
Uninspired.
Underachieving."


There have been improvements, the "exo chip disaster" has been mediated. It isn't rubbish anymore. Since they implemented a way to trade for exo chips things got balanced towards fun again.

and when the update with custom starts hit, people finally got a way to challenge themselves without resorting to mods. So creative potential is again possible.

I would now give Astroneer a passing grade now that some of those mayor issues of mine have been adressed. Starting a new game with noting from Atrox is fun. I would not do it "hardcore", but it is still challenging to find everything and get your starting setup none the less.

The Sandbox feels like a sandbox again. Astronium trades and custom starts ftw ^^

Would I recommend buying it at full price? that is a trickier question, I'd say in these trying times to keep your sanity pay when you can afford a little escapism to stay sane in this mad world.

When I first bought this game I was 15 and all I had was a desktop mac, so I couldn't play it. by the time I had realized my mistake (the game not being able to run on mac) I had owned it too long to refund it. I spent the next 4 years wanting to play, and when I finally got a PC, I tried it. unfortunately it was a laptop and I had tried to play with trackpad, so the game was near unplayable. now that I finally have a Desktop PC with an external mouse, I can finally leave the review this game deserves. this game was worth that ~6 year wait, and now that I have the time to play it and enjoy it, it has quickly become one of my favorite games. I can only give this game a positive review, despite the wait and rough relationship I had had with it in the past, I can't help but love this game. I'd really suggest this game, as it works well to zone out and chill, or actively exploring and focusing on the game.

I REALLY wanted to like this game but unfortunately it didn't deliver in the ways I expected it would. TLDR: Poor mechanics, indirect path, mid tutorial. 

I asked myself "What do I actually want to do here?" around the two hour mark. I refunded the game when I couldn't answer that question.


Controls (Keyboard + Mouse)
This is one of those third-person games where you have to control the camera at the same time as your character, which I personally dislike. I constantly found myself disoriented due to the camera's controls. The settings didn't offer me a better experience. It would make much more sense to me if the camera was locked behind your character or if this was a first-person game. I was hoping to find an accessibility option that would lock the camera but one doesn't exist.

The Tutorial
The tutorial was pretty passive. You're prompted to complete different quests and you're rewarded with some materials and more quests. The tutorial experience feels less educational and more like a series of fetch quests. After you're done with those, there's no guidance in terms of what to do next. I was imagining a Minecraft-esque game set in space where I go around, explore the world's secrets, and eventually travel to other planets (which is what late-game entails, judging from other reviews), but the beginning is so slow and misguided that not only did I have questions about what to do on the main planet, but I had absolutely no idea how I would eventually leave to see other planets. I felt no encouragement to continue. That brings me to...

Tethers
Tethers are the main way you explore the world around you. In order to breathe, you need to place tethers to connect you back to your home base, otherwise you'll gradually lose oxygen and pass out. This makes sense, and I initially liked having a breadcrumb trail back to my base, but the execution is so poor. You literally have to place a tether every five steps your character takes. Later in the game you can make a buggy which eliminates the need for tethers, but the reliance on tethers early-game killed my motivation to explore the world and discover what it has to offer. I didn't feel like I was playing to explore, I felt like I was playing to make more tethers so that I could explore. What started out as a pro turned into an insane setback.
Again, EVERY FIVE STEPS. 

Building and Comprehension
A big part of early-game is building different machines. The game uses technical language that is still accessible, but I can see ESL learners struggling with comprehension. I'm a native English speaker and sometimes had to reread directions in order to understand what I had to do / where something had to go. I did have to turn to a wiki within the first half hour of game play because of this.
The buildings themselves are occasionally a bit confusing as well. The printers are straightforward enough (put in materials, out comes a structure). I think there were some generators that I left alone because I didn't know how they worked. The main point to make here is with the resource collection machine. You find these large hunks of material throughout the world, and they can be broken down (supposedly) by this machine. The tutorial instructed me to build the machine, place it, and put some of this specific material inside of it. I did that, and the machine started moving... and nothing happened. For the whole two hours of game play. If I was doing something wrong, nothing about the machine itself nor the tutorial told me I was. Being confused is a huge deterrent for me in video games.

Loneliness
When playing in single-player, this world is very lonely! I expected some passive and / or hostile creatures somewhere. I don't know if I just didn't get far enough into the game to find them, but I never encountered any. The lack of life on these planets creates an insane loneliness. Sure, it's set in space and there wouldn't be / maybe couldn't be Earth life forms, but I see a huge missed opportunity to create alien life forms that the player can encounter. While I didn't try it out, I understand that multiplayer offers a better experience, but I don't want to spend $30 on a game so that I can tell my friend to spend $30 on a game so we can have fun together.

Farming
This is a smaller point, which is why I put it near the end of this review. You encounter plants occasionally when you're moving around the planet. You can harvest their seeds and then re-plant them at your home base. Many of these plants are dangerous (they explode, they hurt you if you touch them, etc). I realized pretty quickly that there's no real reason to re-plant them unless if you want to put dangerous things near your home. Maybe they're used later in the game for excavation? For defense in a multiplayer world? I wish I could answer these questions.

Conclusion
All of the reviews I saw where people had several hundreds of hours sunk into the game encouraged me to give it a try, and I suppose I encourage you to do the same. What annoys me might not annoy you, and I don't want you to pass on the game just because of my opinion, especially since I didn't get far beyond early-game. If the game offered more freedom and a more story-driven tutorial, potentially with NPCs to help you out and make the world feel more alive, it would have met my expectations. As of right now, I don't regret refunding the game.

I would recommend Astroneer. There is so much to love but also some areas where the devs have fallen short but there is always tomorrow. Astroneer's base and factory building system is easy to understand so even beginners can use the features Astroneer provides. The problem is that the devs aren't adding too much new content to better the game but rather focus on skins and side objectives. I say all this but I love the game and could play is for 100s more hours. Astroneer is a beautiful game  with satisfying game elements. I highly recommend.

I have this game on a different computer, so i've actually played about 223 hours, and this game is great. I think I now understand the 'MEANING OF ASTRONEER' - Here's why you should play it

creative is all about practising for survival, building goofy vehicles and most importantly,
SLIDES. SLIDES AND SLIDES AND SLIDES. But honestly, when you have no friends (relatable) You should just chill on creative.

Playing survival is great with friends. this isn't a guide so I won't tell you what to do, but always remember to mess around and have fun. be stupid and try and trap your friends in a hole and suffocate them. cause' that's what friends are for.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game is not for the loot bug gamer. So little space to carry new things you find. As you unlock things sure you can store more but you can never carry more on you. in fact as you progress in tech you have to lose slots to that tech thus having you carry less and progress slower with each trip.
Edit, can't believe I forgot to mention my biggest nuisance with this game. I grow tired of having to right click and hold to move my camera around to see what i am wanting.
Just expect to spend a lot of time with no real feeling progress despite what you did being productive.

[h1][b] ASTRONEER [/b][/h1] [b][i]ENG BELOW[/i][/b]
Lądujemy na planecie Sylva, nie znając naszej misji. Z czasem jednak odkrywamy tajemnice układu słonecznego, w którym się znajdujemy. Gra posiada bardzo przejrzyste i jednolite mechaniki. Od razu wiadomo, co jak działa i do czego służy. W połączeniu ze spójną grafiką robi to dobre wrażenie. Do dyspozycji mamy mnóstwo pojazdów, narzędzi oraz struktur, które pomogą nam w podbijaniu planet. W grze czekają nas różnorodne zadania, dzięki którym zgłębimy historię świata, w którym się znajdujemy. Jeśli chodzi o aspekt wieloosobowy, gra sprawdza się doskonale, zapewniając mnóstwo zabawy. Jedyne, do czego można się przyczepić, to nagrody za wykonywanie misji, które zbyt łatwo ułatwiają grę, oraz brak endgameu po wykonaniu wszystkich zadań -no chyba że ktoś chce bardziej zająć się automatyką i zbudować imperium przemysłowe.
[hr][/hr]
We land on the planet Sylva, not really knowing our mission. But over time, we uncover the secrets of the solar system we're in. The game has super clear and straightforward mechanics. You instantly know how everything works and what it's all for. Combined with the cohesive graphics, it gives off a good vibe. We've got a ton of vehicles, tools, and structures at our disposal to help conquer planets. The game throws various missions at us, letting us dive into the story of the world we're in. In terms of multiplayer, the game is a blast, providing loads of fun. The only complain would be the rewards for missions, which make the game a bit too easy, and the lack of an endgame after completing all missions—unless someone wants to get more into automation and build an industrial empire.

This was one of my favorite games.  There is so much to explore, collect, and build.  The challenges help you learn and are progressive.  Once you've sort-of mastered things, you realize the reason for automated systems.  It allows you to really get creative.  There isn't much you can't do in this game.  Building with others is a blast, and allows for things you didn't think of.  Just remember to respect each other, and allow areas for each other; or planets for that matter since everyone likes the differences of planets to work from.  My only request of the designers is to allow for weather, planetary events, NPC's, and an actual goal to accomplish.  Seems the game is kinda of lacking without the occasional random event that forces you to react.  Unfortunately, once you have reached a certain level, the game becomes repetitive.  I would suggest for the continuation of success of the game the developers come up with a story line, and an actual goal to complete.  As of now, it's a great game, but needs a touch more.

Super adorable gem of a game which reminds me of the time when I wanted to become an astronaut as a kid. It takes a different approach than the usual loop of killing stuff and leveling - like probably 95% of other games. It's more about exploration, creativity and discovery. It's very relaxing but somehow still manages to be always fun, exciting and build up tension. There is definitely the ...just 10 more minutes effect and trying to build some crazy automated system becomes your new life goal.

What I really don't like are the microtransactions. It's just for cosmetics and they are optional (that's why it doesn't affect my opinion of the game too much) but I passionately hate them and the prices are ridiculous and unfair. I just wish developers would stop doing this sh*t. On the positive side they are constantly improving the game and adding free content, so I guess something for something.
Another (minor) negative point are the controls, which can be a little bit annoying and confusing at times, but nothing too bad.

Overall the game is fantastic though and I can definitely recommend it!

I was so looking forward to play this game. But it has been a long time since I have been so frustrated at a game because I didn't know what to do. The first thing that bothered me was that you start the game, the rockets lands and then a pop up manual shows up that covers an awesome animation (which I saw later in a youtube video) of how the station unfolds. You can hear that something is happening but can't see it. You know that you miss out on something and that is the first thing that happens in this game. Why the manual doesn't pop up after this animation is beyond me.

Then the manual explains some stuff. But not how to do the first things you encounter. So I go to the task list, it says to unpack the backpack. Where is the backpack? No clue. I search everywhere, in the rocket, in the debris that is around the landing zone. I look again in the manual. Nothing. I search again the whole landing zone, look at every object lying around. I had to look up a video, it turns out that you need to accept the first task that you completed to get the backpack. HOW SHOULD I KNOW THAT? Then you need to collect Reisin. How does it look like? Where can you find it? How do you collect it? No clue. Why is there no tutorial that explains the first things you need to do in the game. I had to rage quit. This is unacceptable.

It takes a few hours to understand how the game works... the controls are just awful. I have played over 20 hours and I am still struggling with those controls occasionally. The game doesn't provide much guidance on how things work, you have to figure everything out yourself. In the game, there are some annoying bugs, such as getting stuck in the ground or if your friend comes too close, you might get stuck as well (happens occasionally). 

If you enjoy exploring planets and collecting materials, this game is for you (assuming you can handle poor controls). With friends the game is much more enjoyable. And at last, don't buy this at full price, it's not worth it.

9.3/10

Will try to keep the below as spoiler-free as possible.

[b]Pros:[/b]
 - Very satisfying exploration / production gameplay loop.  The environments are all interesting, and the risk of death / danger is always there, but not in an intrusive way. The fundamental themes of my experience were awe and curiosity.
 - Well-constructed Solo campaign leads you through a good experience feeling out all of the games features and ideas in a way where it always feels like there are many things to do and learn and see.  It's also not overly long to the point where it feels grindy or infinite; there is always a goal and it's always within reach, right up until everything is done.
 - The types of automation you can accomplish (while very limited, see below) do feel very cool to do.
 - The research bytes mechanic is a neat way to incentivize and reward exploration.

[b]Cons:[/b]
 - The controls are clunky, unintuitive, and awkward; even after dozens of hours.  I find myself still mixing up Q, E, and F even now after 90+ hours played.  In hindsight, I think they are as good as they could be, so it's not a bad implementation -- it's just difficult to get used to.  There is a lot of functionality smashed into basically 3-4 buttons which you use for everything. This ends up being a nice thing at times too, so I don't disagree with the design choice; but I do see this could be a barrier to enjoyment for some players.
 - There are hints of automation throughout the game, but they never end up feeling like a "closed form solution" to me.  I went into it with an expectation that while I, the player character, will have to do a lot of the "work" necessary with my own two hands, eventually some of the more common tasks I would be able to automate away.  This ends up being only partially true, but almost always in the form of making the manual process [i]easier[/i], and not making manual processes [b]unnecessary[/b] (which is what I was hoping for).
 - Quite a few of the element behaviors are really unintuitive (repeaters, the crane, sensors, anything with a Reaction Pin); once you understand them they do all make good sense, but trying to discover them without any external guidance sometimes felt frustrating and unrewarding.
 - Some of the gameplay elements are just sandbox fun gimmicks more than functional tools; while I don't have an issue with this in general, I do wish I could clearly tell which things were meant just for fun, and which were meant to serve a purpose.  Sometimes you see something in the tech tree and you form all sorts of ideas about what it could be or what you might do with it, then you finally build one and it's basically a paperweight.

astonishing atmosphere through and through. absolutely fantastic soundtrack, too. simple design with intuitive gameplay. great alone, great with friends. a welcoming break from all those tiresome survival grinding games, this one can be finished in way less time than most others like minecraft or valheim. a beautiful and creative game about discovery that is quite relaxing and comfy.
But one problem still persists: the camera. It's moving too much, it's too close or too far, your char/vehicle is obstructing what you want to see, etc.
One simple thing would solve this: a toggleable first person view. Even if player model just turns invisible this would be the solution for every one of those problems that players have been requesting for 5 years now. For every action you don't want to have first person cam you could just switch it automatically, but driving with a rover or the train in FP would be soooo good and immersive. Please, just fix this already. I'd love this game SO much more than I already do.

It took me and a friend 45 hours to 100% the game.  If you are looking for a fun coop game to play with your friend, this is a good one.  I will say though, without spoiling anything, make sure to kind of take your time when drilling your caves.  Smooth is fast! 

I will say that there were some weird achievement things where we had to go back and do something over again for me because it didn't register the first time like for the scanner things.  We had to make 7 more and do them for me, which wasn't a huge deal but I feel like we shouldn't have had to do that.  Just make sure you both or all of you do the proximity beacons because it is local-based.

Overall, fun experience and I thought the trains were the coolest part of the whole thing.  We only built two train systems but especially on the home planet, it was convenient to go get some materials that we needed.  

Make sure to invest in good power structure!

text is blurry and unbelievably small. I'm playing on a TV, not a steam deck, and I still can barely even read it. 
https://imgur.com/a/WBJnVtW this is an unchanged screenshot from the game. notice how some letters are completely illegible. this is only 1/3 of the screen. so if you look at this fullscreen, it's 3x as big
yes, this blurry, frizzy pixel mess is 4k ultra on almost everything (except shadows are high). this looks like a bad screenshot from a 2000s game. the font itself is already borderline illegible - typical apple like style over function font, pure hell for people with dyslexia (which I don't have, but I feel how much effort I have to put in to even read it)

what's worse is that every text fizzles and transforms around for 2-3 seconds until letters don't overlap any more every time you see a popup in the game world.
you can't read anything until you literally give the text time to render in a barely legible fashion, which is most of the time still blurry, frizzy and illegible. it almost looks like it is coming apart at the seems. (I run everything on ultra and 4k and have a 4090 and a 7950x3D)

it is incredibly annoying and off-putting. it feels like the dev went to a considerable amount of effort to make *everything* with numbers or letters in this game awful.

this isn't a bug on my end. this is, according to searches I did in the comments, an issue that has existed for years. yet the dev refuses to fix it.

that's why I believe there are a lot of reviews for this game from a time where it was in early access and people assumed it would get fixed. but it didn't get fixed.

sure, after like 50h, you probably do not need to read anything anymore, so it won't upset the die hard fanbois that are convinced this open world survival craft copy paste #87562786 is the best game ever.

but being unable to read popup windows in a game that refuses to follow normal control schemes and common game logic is infuriating.

it's the typical "dev tried to reinvent the wheel" syndrome. 

when you open the game, you get an uninterruptable ad for the "support packs". the game tells you you can hit esc to quit out of it, but it does not react to hitting that key until a few seconds have passed. I'm sure that's just a "bug".
speaks volumes about what is going on with this project.

this is another case where the steam ratings are dubious... I'm sure you can have some fun in this game, but there's dozens of games like this out there that do not actively try to piss off newcomers with font and a text rendering method that can't be read and weird game logic that's very unique to this game and feels wrong

Addictive. Once I unlocked trains I never looked back.

Several parts of it do feel unfinished/unpolished however. It does seem kinda annoying that you have to pretty much max your tech tree to get the a vehicle that can do both actions needed to build a road at the same time. It basically meant that by the time I could build roads I already had trains going to everywhere I needed to be.

I definitely did a lot of things out of order and there are several glitches to worry about including a persistent issue of items clipping through the ground and disappearing and it seems like I'm not the only one for whom the Wanderer refuses to trigger. Good news is they aren't gone forever and even if you lose items in the planet's core you can eventually get them back.

I wish that the dedicated server provided was slightly less completely broken so that I could host a dedicated server to share a persistent world with my friends. I have a literal server rack in my basement and it won't run stably enough for me to be worth it and it can only be run on linux if you disable encryption which... no

The seasonal events are a fun little bonus on top, but the cosmetics and emotes feel mostly like a reminder of the fact that I'm playing alone. There mass item storage canisters are super useful but by the time I got to them there didn't seem to be enough stuff left to build that needed mass resources for their to be a call for them. Maybe if I wanted to farm Scrap for an event or something?

Speaking of Scrap it's also pretty unclear through normal gameplay how you are intended to collect and scrap all of the destroyed gear that you find that's too big to fit into your inventory. It's a hassle to lug around manually and doesn't snap to anything and packagers seem like a waste. It wasn't until much later in the game where I though about adding a whole extra rover to my train just to drag a shredder around and using it is really power hungry so that feels like a dumb way to go about it.

Overall it's cute and worth your time, but it feels like a late-stage beta that needed some rework that it isn't going to get because it got pushed to prod and it's already making money.

Very solid open world space survival base building and crafting game that provides the option for Online Co-op.  It features terraforming mechanics and the ability to travel from planet to planet via spaceship.  Items to collect and discover in the game present logistical challenges depending on the storage and transport technology the player is currently utilizing.  This gives progression in the game a more meaningful purpose.  Power and oxygen distribution are also key elements that the player needs to manage in order to safely traverse the various environments/biomes.

There are plenty of gadgets, buildings and vehicles for the player to unlock and use to continue their quest of progressing technology and uncovering the lore of the universe.  What's particularly satisfying is the capability to make a mobile base such that vehicles and ships aren't simply a faster way to traverse the planets you explore.  Not to mention the fact that you can fit ground vehicles with mining drills allowing you to excavate tunnels and collect resources at a much faster and efficient rate.

The cartoony art style and color palate might be a turn off for some players, but the content and gameplay loop of Astroneer is certainly top notch, especially for players that want a more chill exploration and survival flow to the game that isn't constantly bombarding them with enemies to kill or raids on their base(s).

If you're into survival crafting and base building games set in space, Astroneer is certainly worth giving a try.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I usually don't leave reviews this early in the play time but this game TO ME is trash! Dev there is a difference in telling me to do something vs how to do it, tutorial is supposed to at a bare minimum teach you to use the controls right? Maybe all these games I play got it wrong? Nope, this game is just terrible. I thought it was going to be like No Mans Sky just a little more chilled, Nope! The controls are crazy, there are no instructions about how to use anything! I've played less than 2 hours and that is not straight, I played for a minute got frustrated said I'll come back when I'm not so ____ (fill in the blank with anything!)  I came back 4 more times (I seem get frustrated with this game super quick).

1 example: Fill the soil canister with soil, sounded like an easy task, until you have no idea where to put the canister, how to get the soil in it and what do you do after (beside click the big green button) you've collected this sample. After about 20 minutes I finally figured out (not really I was just click on stuff hoping it would work) how to fill the canister.

I usually don't like combat and try to avoid it in games that I can, but I will do a better job (I'm not a gamer, programmer by trade) in No Mans Sky combat than this supposedly calm exploration game that makes exploration next to impossible.

This is why I like to invest in EA games, at least then if you tell the Dev 3/4 of the controls/game makes no sense things can be changed but games like this, you can only warn others that this game is not what you think and it don't work like you think it should. (controls are not intuitive at all)

Now could this just be a me thing, No I asked an actual gamer to try this game out and they said the controls are just terrible. Some of this is probably just me I like software/games to just work, shouldn't have to go watch Youtube vids just to figure out the basic mechanics (controller usage) of the game. This was a waste of my Steam Christmas money.

Lets start with the negative aspects of the game.
Now that we are over it lets talk about the positive.Fluid game mechanics that bind well with the aesthetic of the game and its overall feel making it seamlessly transition from one activity to the next.
The building aspect  is based on a system of modular platforms,each item occupies a certain amount of space(small mid large slot) requiring a simple drag and drop top assemble making the building easy for a newcomer but it also offers logic blocks[strike] in case you are not content with your daytime engineering job[/strike].
The resource management can be automated  with the help of various machinery as mentioned before but in order to unlock it you must explore multiple planets  trying to balance your power an oxygen while finding various treasures making it highly addictive.
This review is merely scratching the surface of this fantastic title,while i cant say if this is the game for you, in my humble opinion it is worth it

[h1] To preface this review, [/h1]
I have carefully followed its rough early development and played this game since the pre-alpha in 2016.
(R.I.P Paul Pepera)

To put it lightly, the game has changed SIGNIFICANTLY since the 2016 release date.
Almost every facet of the game has been improved significantly.

[h2] ALMOST. [/h2]

[b] This game is SO CLOSE to perfection it's insane. [/b]

[olist]
[*]The visuals are pretty, stylized, and performant on most mid-range to high-end hardware
[*]Progression is straightforward and easy to follow thanks to guiding missions
[*]Building is simple and versatile, very similar to Legos™
[*]Item/Inventory organization is very intuitive and visual
[/olist]

I would HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone who enjoys open-world space exploration games with deform-able voxel terrain.

However, it's not all sunshine and rainbows, there is one major shortcoming (at least in my personal opinion).
This section is the main focus of my review of this game:

[h2] The Story [/h2]

[b] *DISCLAIMER* [/b]
Please DO NOT read further into this review and/or click on the blacked out text if you want to experience the current in game story line yourself or don't care about the story.

[spoiler] 
Ok, I'll keep this as short as possible: 
Writing that the entire game world is "in a simulation" is really lazy writing in my personal opinion. 
It completely annihilates the requirement of following real science or realism, and allows for writers to write literally anything into the story without much effort or thought. 

For example: Fortnite Battle Royale
Fortnite Battle Royale's story at one point devolved completely into [i] oooh wow there's this thingy called the ZERO POINT that is canonically linked with every universe in existence so we can now write literally anything from anywhere else into the game because we can[/i] Sarcasm aside, it really sucked to see the writers get this lazy to add such a crutch for extra content.

Ok, enough about Fortnite, this review is about Astroneer.
The only part about the main simulation focused story line that I find compelling is the whole point of the player progressing and exploring to restore the lost memories of a missing colleague in the EXO Dynamics company. I think that that's an interesting way to spin the status quo, however, it really limits the creativity of the writers in terms of what they can do next in the story. [/spoiler]

Now onto my final point of the review:

[h3] Good Video Game Lore Isn't Told Directly To The Player. [/h3]

There.
I said it.

A game's lore is at it's peak when the entire community has different ideas about how it's structured, each with their own nuance and opinions on interpretations of subtle clues left by the developers to gently nudge them in the right direction.

This is called "Quasi-Lore", and the hit game Minecraft has probably the best implementation of this in the entire gaming industry by far.

To help explain, here's a YouTube video I found about it:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4KDybLytYtk

The old versions of Astroneer actually had this style of lore in it, with a bunch of wreckages and dead players scattered underground on each planet and moon, indirectly communicating to the player that there have been many previous failed attempts to colonize the system you are currently exploring.

This made the mood/atmosphere of the game feel a lot more dark and dystopian, like you were EXO Dynamics's last hope in making a successful foothold in the system for the company, 

or even for your entire race.


The newer versions did away with this entire narrative, instead going for the lazy approach of [spoiler] retconning the whole universe you explore's origin for being from an EXO Dynamics company simulation computer that is trying to recover corrupted files. [/spoiler]

I sincerely hope that this review doesn't steer you away from the game, rather,
I want people who read this review to the end to understand my disappointment for the current story and play it anyway!

If you don't understand my point on the story, that's okay too.
You have a right to disagree with my review, and criticize it as you see fit in its comments.

[h1] TL;DR: [/h1]

[h3] The game is amazing, but don't play if you care about unveiling a great story while you play. [/h3]

This concludes my passionate review of the game Astroneer.
It is what it promises, solid gameplay, good missions, well written.

Game is super fun and I enjoyed all the plot twists! NOTHING IS REAL[/spoiler]. I highly recommend!! Have fun and stay safe, fellow Astroneers!

The idea is pretty cool, but this game has neither mid, nor end-game.

Mid-game is basically just early-game but you have to travel more.

Once you reach the end of mid-game, your end-game begins, by which point you already have everything you need to finish the game, even though NOW is when you can most efficiently collect materials and travel around planets. But finishing the game doesn't require huge sweeps for materials at all, instead it's just tedious busywork copy pasted dozens of times. I genuinely don't know what the devs were thinking here.

There is no post-credits game.

That's it, this game ends when you complete the most basic base setup. It's basically just a fun little experience, until you reach end-game and it becomes a tedious chore. I recommend that you NEVER do the purple things, and just stop playing it on a good note.

[b]TL;DR:[/b] A simple interplanetary exploration with a quite neat story to discover. A few rough edges, but not enough to drag it down. If the aesthetics and feeling that the trailers and screenshots give off hooked you, then you won't be dissatisfied, these are the main catches of the game. Plus, custom difficulty options can help you if you feel things are too hard (or too easy).

Somewhere, I wish this game had more. A more throrough crafting system, with longer production chains and stronger automation. Exploration with more side objectives other than "find nexus, reach core, collect resources".

But I'm glad the game is what it is. It stays on the simple side, and that's where its strenghts lies. Similar to how Minecraft is visually simple to understand (one of its main strenghts), both in aesthetics and mechanics, Astroneer is visually simple in a way that is relaxing and easy on you. It does a great job of minimizing UI, since you can see suit power, suit oxygen, and what you're carrying directly on your astronaut. Everything is direct, simple to see and understand, and straightforward.

In mechanics, learning the crafting resources is simple, and the game even has a built-in guide, so no need to open a wiki because you forgot where to find Hematite, or which mineral refines into Zinc. Exploration is only hindered by oxygen, which is dealt with placing theters that bring oxygen (which is done with one button press, easy). Traveling between planets can be done with resources found on all planets, so there's no risk of getting stranded (but do carry an extra thruster with you, in case launch bugs out and burns the thruster or you select the wrong destination). There is no set order to explore, and you can decide where to go by checking the recipes unlocked and decide what you're working towards.

Enemies are a bit of a problem. One plant in particular shoots a homing bubble of gas even through terrain. You'll learn to hear it and immediately go into panic mode, trying to find it and uprooting it as soon as possible. Others, you'll learn what they do when you step on them, and by then it will be too late. The sound design on these ones is awful, the sound is sharp and immediate, without any fade in, which gives them a audio-based jump-scare factor, since the music and other sounds are so muted and calm.

The game got missions sometime after launch of 1.0, which are kinda nice in giving pointers on what to do (and pieced a nice narrative), but also kinda detracted from the free-form exploration. The rewards from them are quite nice, and serve as good kickstarters. Don't feel tied to them if that's your thing. You can ignore them and then just pick up the rewards later for just playing the game later (or don't pick up the rewards at all, no one's your boss).

The music ties the whole package perfectly. While it's unlikely you'll have a favorite track, none of them will ever feel bad, out of place, or inappropriate for the setting.

Astroneer catapults players into a mesmerizing universe filled with wonder and limitless exploration, creating an enchanting gaming experience that captures the essence of space exploration. From the outset, the game greets you with a visually stunning and vibrant open world, inviting you to embark on a journey of discovery across diverse planets.

The sandbox nature of Astroneer allows for a personalized adventure, encouraging creativity and ingenuity as you shape the environment to suit your needs. The joy of terraforming, molding the terrain to uncover resources, and constructing intricate bases is immensely satisfying, fostering a deep connection between player and planet.

The cooperative multiplayer aspect of Astroneer enhances the enjoyment, allowing friends to join forces and collaborate in shaping the cosmos. The seamless integration of multiplayer into the game's core mechanics ensures that teamwork not only feels natural but also exponentially amplifies the fun factor.

Astroneer's art style is a testament to its charm, with a delightful mix of minimalist aesthetics and intricate details. The soundtrack complements the serene yet adventurous atmosphere, creating an immersive backdrop for your cosmic escapades.

One of the standout features is the absence of a traditional narrative, allowing players to create their own stories and goals. The sense of freedom is empowering, and the game's commitment to player agency is a refreshing departure from more linear gaming experiences.

In conclusion, Astroneer is a triumph in the exploration and survival genre, seamlessly blending creativity, cooperative play, and stunning visuals. Whether you're a lone astronaut carving your path through the cosmos or part of a team shaping entire worlds, Astroneer promises an enchanting odyssey that celebrates the spirit of limitless discovery.

Ah, another time Steam needs a "mixed" option.

If the game seems interesting to you, I'd say to give it a shot - but for me, it lost that cool discovery vibe it had when I got it so many years ago.

Ever since they added missions, the game's progression has been thoroughly ruined.

You now get most of the essentials within the first few hours, and it makes research feel kind of redundant due to that.

Sure, there's a lot more stuff to research - but most of it is variations on stuff you probably won't use, and it feels nicer to get a neat small unlock every so often vs. some big one after 10 hours.

Some updates have tried to fix it, but the best way in my opinion is to remove blueprint rewards from missions, and have them give either resources or a small amount of bytes.

You can really feel the difference if you're able to play a pre-missions build of the game vs. a post-missions one. Progression is just following the linear quests the game lays out, and it detracts from an otherwise unique experience.

The mission system itself is also quite handholdy and just feels kind of condescending at times - like the devs think you're so stupid you can't figure out the basics of a game.

Some updates have tried to rectify a few of the more annoying aspects of the game (such as transporting more than 8 items out of a cave at a time), but it's still not quite as good as it needs to be imo.

The repetitive events are also quite draining. It'd be nice if you could get some of the cosmetic shop currency at the top reward tier, but as-is you just kinda get random items you can already get fairly easily by just playing the game. When combined with how samey all of them are (plop items onto a unique building and click "send"), it makes all of these events blend together in your head while also making them rather unfun.

I don't wanna say Astroneer has fallen to rock bottom or anything like that, but it definitely left my favourites list quite some time ago. I'd rather get no updates than constant recycled events clogging up my feed that barely give you anything, so why would I reinstall the game just to play them?

As I said at the start though, it is worth playing if it looks interesting to you - but I'm disappointed they didn't stick with the more Terraria/Minecraft-style approach of "here's some cool shit, play the game and find out how it works"

I've played many a space game in my lifetime, and none scratches the itch of exploration such as Astroneer. Though a bit grindy, anyone of any age can pick up this game and understand the core goals despite the rather open-endedness of the game.

Astroneer is a survival sandbox with surprisingly rich story, pleasantly simple graphics, and probably the least annoying inventory management system in all of video games. It's not a game you can beat in a few hours, and you sure as heck don't want to. I've 100 percented the game through Gamepass and I'm on my 5th run starting on steam. It's a delightful game, great alone or with friends.

Astroneer is a captivating and visually stunning game that invites players to embark on an interstellar adventure like no other. From the moment I stepped onto an alien planet, I was entranced by the game's vibrant colors, imaginative landscapes, and the sense of wonder that permeates every corner of its vast, procedurally generated universe.

One of the standout features of Astroneer is the sheer freedom it offers players to shape and mold their surroundings. The terraforming mechanics are not only innovative but also a testament to the game's commitment to letting players forge their own path. Whether it's crafting intricate structures or reshaping the terrain to suit your needs, the possibilities seem almost limitless.

However, Astroneer does not hold your hand, and therein lies its charm. While it may take some time to grasp the intricacies of resource gathering and crafting, this learning curve adds a layer of depth to the gameplay. The satisfaction that comes with mastering these mechanics is unparalleled. It's a journey of trial and error, discovery, and ultimately triumph as you begin to harness the full potential of your astronaut's capabilities.

Resource management is a key aspect of Astroneer, and yes, it does take some patience to gather the necessary materials for more advanced constructions. But this slow burn only enhances the sense of achievement when you finally unlock that next technological milestone. Each step forward feels earned, making the game a rewarding experience for those willing to invest the time and effort.

The multiplayer aspect of Astroneer is another gem in its crown. Joining forces with friends to explore the cosmos, collaborate on projects, and overcome challenges adds a social dynamic that elevates the overall gaming experience. The sense of camaraderie as you work together to establish a thriving base on an alien world is truly special.

In conclusion, Astroneer is a stellar exploration game that beckons players to embrace the unknown and revel in the joy of discovery. While it may take a bit of time to fully grasp its mechanics and gather the resources needed for certain advancements, the payoff is well worth the investment. Dive into the captivating world of Astroneer and let your inner explorer soar among the stars.

I do not recommend this game at all.
First things first, so many of its features feel incredibly disconnected, there are like 50 different things to do and it never feels rewarding or necessary to do 45 of them. 

Secondly it really feels like the game has no respect at all for the time you put in. You can spend hours prepping for a trip to the most dangerous planet, Atrox and upon landing your ship instantly gets blown to smithereens by a single explosion, not only killing you, but also destroying all the gear you had stored on that ship and sending you back to the starting planet, without your ship

It does not matter how much time you spent preparing, you will loose it all in a near unpreventable way without warning. The best strategy for that Planet isn't to go in as prepared as possible, but to throw yourself at it with disposable gear as often as  possible until you retrieve what you need. But even that isn't really possible, because you need to [spoilers:] [spoiler]Bring three items to the planets core[/spoiler] to unlock the games ending. doesn't help, that without a drill mod you cant dig there at all, so have fun needing to replace that too

This is a pattern the game repeats again and again. Without warning it throws you into a situation you couldn't prepare for, takes away all your hard earned gear and throws you back to square one. 
There is no reason to remove your items if you die retrieving them, but the game does it anyway, just to slap you in the face.

This is repeated again and again, the game really punishes you for engaging with it

If i weren't such goddamned completionist and hadn't already exceeded refund time on this game i would not open the game again. This game feels insulting to play.

Edit: scratch that last part, im just gonna remove it from my account anyways, after playing a bit more and getting spat in the face a few more times i decided its not worth it. There are 2 games that achieve everything this game does, but better. If you want the exploration and at least slightly less clunky gravity, play outer wilds. For the factory building on an alien planet, just play satisfactory.

but the bugs were the highlight for me, tinkering on how to break the game in the funniest ways, to cheese gameplay mechanics and to break the physics engine to bring my computer to a crawl.
the game is more refined and no longer has such extensive bugs, but i still manage to find them and the challenge to find them is my favorite aspect. maybe not the thing the devs want to hear, but it is true. the most recent exploit I had found, that only one other person that i know knew of was one to "trade scam" where you take the scrap from the trade platfrom as it leaves to get resources. i automated it with the arms and made a resource factory giving me infinite everything. they patched it, haven't found anything since, except minor glitches here and there.

outside of my gameplay experience I think this game is worth it for anyone to try out. very relaxing gameplay
awesome game, perfect mix of sci fi and science and indie games
