Giving a negative review for two reasons:
1. The camera controls on keyboard and mouse are needlessly terrible. The most sensible control scheme, holding right click to unlock the cursor, is not a possible option, instead you need to be in a weird toggle situation or running around constantly holding right click down so the camera makes any sense. This is not the case on controller, where you hold a button down to unlock the cursor. Absolutely baffling design.
2. The camera smoothing and automatic rotation of it is nauseating, and has been an issue for a long time, to the point that if you want to not deal with it, you have to download a dll on Github and inject it into your .exe just to change something that should be a setting.

It's a shame because I do like this game, but it's a pain to play. You will likely HAVE to play it on a controller

After rethinking, I will recommend this game. 

This game doesn't have a lot of content, and gets boring after 5-ish hours. But, the game is also a pre-alpha. The core mechanics aren't even there yet. Plus, the things needed to implement new mechanics, (Terrain 2.0, Research 2.0) also aren't there yet. 

[b]Understand this is a pre-alpha game, it will take time to get good[b]

Don't buy it expecting to get a fully complete game. But if you want to support a dev team, go for it.

Updating this review to say disregard above, this is complete game worth your money and time now. Also runs great on Linux Mint 21.1 so should run great on steam deck.

Really want to like the game, but it lies to you and thinks it's far better than it is.  It doesn't keep incremental saves, and it will happily eat your resources.  It lets you connect rovers together, but the physics engine can't support it.  The game thinks it is quite a bit better than it is.

I want to like it, because a lot of the core concepts are good and fun.  But you can't just have items that you can research that are flat out broken.  You can't have physics that completely destroy an entire night's worth of effort, and have no way to recover a previous save.

Astroneer, the intergalactic fiesta of wonders and cooperative escapades! With procedurally generated planets that pop like confetti, visuals so vibrant they'd make a disco jealous, and an interface friendlier than a cosmic kitten, this game is the life of the gaming galaxy party.

But hold your jetpacks, because what truly sets Astroneer apart is its groovy emphasis on collaboration. It's like a multiplayer dance-off where players share resources, and together, they build a cosmic tapestry that's more psychedelic than a neon rainbow.

Now, grab your Fanta, because as we sip on that fizzy delight, ponder the nomadic vibes of Mongolia, and throw in some communism for good measure, Astroneer becomes a party that transcends pixels. It's a celebration of unity, cultural richness, and exploration that's wilder than a unicorn riding a skateboard.

In conclusion, Astroneer is the cosmic rave that keeps evolving with updates and community shenanigans. It's a journey that tickles the imagination and unites players in the joy of discovery. Here's to Astroneer – the shining star in the gaming galaxy, where even the aliens do the cha-cha! 🚀✨

Game is absolutely worth its price. I enjoyed many hours of exploring, playing and beating the game. However, below are a few remarks that could and should be implemented, I assume most are in the works for the long term. 

1. If the creators want the game to be explored as it sits, great, but once you beat the game. It should give you an option to restart with knowledge. 

2. A building aspect seems the only natural route this game is going to take, but understandably you want it to stand out. So maybe have a building aspect, after someone has beaten the game. Restart with or without technologies, but allow building, so people can build entire communities. A method to reset a planet would be cool, like a "reset charge" (Marvel's Loki Series) that can be set by the owner of the server or host, etc... This way, if a moon has been hollowed out, or a planet, it can be periodically reset but it literally wipes it clean. Be cool to see it randomize resources, but that's a 2025 problem. 

3. Add weapons, allow pvp, so people could host capture the flag worlds, or hunger game worlds. Hell, imagine building an entire fortress world then having to defend it from attacks. Or even maze worlds, or different pre-generated worlds for stories, pve or pvp. 

4. Can we get a slingshot pod or something, like a deployable life boat that literally shoots you from one planet to another, you have no choice where you land. This would be cool just so we don't have to build an entire shuttle if we get marooned, I got the inspiration from the TV show Foundation when they use "extraction packets" to escape planet and get back into orbit.

As mentioned this game is great, I would and will always recommend people buy it. Who knows, maybe we will get the dev's attention and some of these suggestions can be implemented. Always down to share more ideas, obviously its a great game, but I could see this game taking over Steam with a few changes.

This is a very fun game playing with a friend, the missions get very hard at a certain point, but then once you get past that point you're not going to regret pushing to get past that point. I think it's terrible to try to play the missions alone though.

There are aspects of the game that require strategic planning or you will get stuck, even up to getting stranded on another planet. Hopefully you have a friend to play with, because they can rescue you if you mess up. I accidentally mouse-clicked the wrong planet one time and my rocket was out of fuel, if I had clicked on the right planet, there was fuel waiting. Yay my hubby rescued me lol.

The camera takes some getting used to and there are some glitches. For instance one of our tractors shot through the ground down several layers into the planet, and was stuck in the void; just because I bumped the tractor walking too close. This time I was able to rescue hubby.

So far as I can tell, there are only dangers of terrain, aggressive plant life, and running out of oxygen.

I think the game could benefit from a few additions but not sure who to talk to about such.

BUT once you get past that, the game world, mechanics, and setting are pretty freaking incredible. If you just want a good scifi inspired sandbox/light survival game. this is it. Just have some patience with the UI and control design.

This game dose a lot of things right. 

BUT: It also makes many many mistakes. After 8 Hours of game play I still fumble with the controls. And that's not because I don't play many video games, I have over 1000 hours in quite a few games. Its because they are clunky. Buttons are seemingly randomly assigned to functions, depending on context. 

The game dose a bad job at explaining itself. Not the basics. The tutorial is quite good, but when I want to know how to enable the drill-mod for the tractor, I have to try buttons, or google it. 

The "grid align" block is absolutely useless, because "grid aligned" means something really technical, that changes depending on position on the planet. This is never explained, nor is it intuitive. Just give me a block that is always perpendicular to gravity. Its not that hard. 

The menu, especially the printer and research menu is structured like a shelf. Neat idea, but a pain to use. No search function. Even tho there are 100s of buildings in the late game. Scrolling with WASD is ok, but you cant scroll while the animation is running, meaning that when I know that I want to switch items fast, it doesn't let me. 

The "printer" in my backpack is a pain to use, because all items are arranged so that I have to click through all of them to find the right one. Late game this is a pain. 

4/10 would not recommend. I seriously don't understand why the reviews are "Overwhelmingly Positive". I can't be the only one with these problems.

Resin.

What can I say. It's great. It used to be just a survival game before the automation update came out. 
With that, the devs refined it to be an automation game too, if you wanted it to be. 
Updates are big packages of good content, events are semi-regular and the in game store only sells cosmetics (some of which you can also earn by playing the earlier mentioned events).
The game itself is very casual, you should not play it if you are looking for a challenge.
Most challenges in this game will be set by you, because your base can always be bigger and your Nano-Alloys could always be more. Also you can make a very big boom out of extracted atmospheric hydrogen.
Speaking of which, your main tool throughout the game will be a giant brush with which you can edit the terrain however you like. Aside from the production devices, there are no preassembled things, you have to brush your house yourself if you want one.
All in all 9/10, some missed opportunities with additional challenges , but the game has developers and a community that both actually care about it.

I loved the game and how it was before. Now it simply became too bland.

[h3]Short elaboration[/h3]

To sum this entire review up, The game lost its satisfaction and charm due to how easy it became.

[h3]Long elaboration[/h3]

In the good old days, the feeling of finally grinding enough bytes to unlock the RTG and getting all the resources required to obtain the nano-carbon alloy required to craft the RTG was unmatched.

Nowadays, all you have to do is research 5 items commonly found in forests, and there you go: a mini-RTG, zero effort, zero grind. The worst thing being that the mini-RTG is even better than the normal one as it works in the exact same way but can actually be equipped in the player's inventory or the buggy, with the only downside being that it produces less energy (maybe?).

The same is true for many other items, which in the good old days you'd have to spend hours grinding for; now you can basically obtain them within 10 minutes of creating your world.

I wouldn't have an issue with this if it was just a one-off thing (you get 1 mini-RTG and that's it), but the thing is that you can get dozens of them within just a few hours (me and my friend played on our co-op world for maybe 5-10 hours and already had like 4 or 5 mini-RTGs alongside several other end-game OP items just laying randomly around *).

This brings me to my next issue. Since the game started spamming the player with so many OP items, in most cases they'll either be put on a storage slot, placed in some random corner of the base, and completely forgotten, or they'll just be randomly thrown around the floor, cluttering the base.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]

[b]Would I recommend the game?[/b] - Absolutely! Don't get me wrong, the game is amazing but will get extremely boring and repetitive after 5–10 hours (before it was more like 100–200 hours). If that is worth $30 ($12 when on sale) to you, then get it! Otherwise, think about it.

HELP I'VE CREATED A MONSTER! I convinced my wife to give this game a try...over 100 hours of co-op play later and she won't let me sleep or eat! Help me!!!

Seriously, it's a very addictive game. Once you start finding you're way to other planets, get the special resources back and learning about the automations you can put together. Something about the resource management and gadgets had really hooked my missus on this game. We put in about 15-20 hours together in a single weekend alone. 

The gadget selection device where you choose which gadgets to research and "purchase" is still the biggest annoyance, even after 50 hours of gameplay it's still a pain to find the exact gadgets.

==============================


In essence you get dumped on a planet with a few pieces of kit and your job is gathering resources, building more useful tools and exploring. Love the graphics, I'm sucker recently for cartoony style graphical games like this and Raft, there's already way too many games chasing realistic graphics and sacrificing gameplay.

If I had to pick on two negative points, the first would be the intro/tutorial or complete lack of one. This game could really do with a much better intro. The comms device with the missions kept telling me to research and make XYZ but didn't make it clear that I needed to pull out the research pad on my backpack, earn the bytes and then buy the plans. Second negative would be research pad where you find new devices to learn and make is not very intuitive and I find myself constantly scrolling through every single item on every list trying to find what I'm looking for, that gets very tedious, very quickly due to the navigation.

Outside the two negatives it's really fun game, quirky style, a little grindy but getting to the really rare and valuable resources takes some skill with the "terrain vacuum" tool, one false move and you slip away from your tether line and you have just a few minutes to get back or reload from last save point, gives it an edge. 


I do like the relaxed game play style, nothing nasty really gets you other than falling into a ravine and then suffocating is generally the worst that will happen to you.

Slapped a Drill on the front of my tractor and it destroyed the floor and dropped me into a hole that was getting dug faster than I could fall into it.  10/10

While this game seems to have been crafted with a lot of creativity and charm, ultimately, it becomes a boring slog.

Astroneer is a very interesting game, at the start. You land on a planet, collect the local resources, construct buildings, upgrades, and research new buildings and upgrades, while collecting more resources. You balance out your power usage, make sure you have enough oxygen, and you can run about doing what ever you want. It is a very creatively made sandbox game that looks great, plays great, and has a ton of charm in the music, graphics, sound effects, and more. 

However, it is not complicated, it will not challenge you in any way. when I say that you need to balance out power usage and oxygen, I don't mean to compare it with something like, Factorio, or other more complex games. In this you just build a single Oxygenator, do some quests to get generators that provide free unlimited power and run on nothing, and you are good to go for the game.

Ultimately though your goal is to *spoilers ahead* activate a strange structure you find on the surface of the planet, which allows you into the core. By doing this: activating a structure on each of the different planets in the system and digging down and activating the cores, you open up a sort of fast travel network. However, by the time you are able to do all of this, you will have already unlocked and done everything there is to make and do. There is no need to travel to other planets for their metals and gases through this portal network, because you have already done so via regular space ship, and have copious quantities.

To entice you into playing more, you are given further things to do. Unlock EVERY strange structure on every planet and moon (6 structures per planet, 2 per moon, for a total of 34), and collect a hidden probe on each planet and moon in order to get a hidden message... and that is about it. Suffice to say, I did not do these time killing tasks. Even while listening to podcasts and watching videos etc. while playing this game to keep myself entertained, I was still getting bored. Maybe it would be more fun with friends in multiplayer?

If you are looking for a VERY uncomplicated sandbox game where, ultimately, you cannot die and there are no real consequences to any actions, where there is no real story, and the true gameplay is the grind, this game will suit you just fine. I kind of wish I could give it a mixed review; but ultimately I was able to get it for a decent price on sale and played for about 70 hours, so I guess ultimately I would have to go with a thumbs up.

It's a space-themed base building game. You'll get to the top of tech tree in about 60 hours if you learn on your own and don't rush. Aiming for maximum exploration/utilising most of the tools game gives you (like automation/railways) isn't necessary for completion, but will easily add 60 hours more to your game.

This game has a cash-shop containing many cosmetics. However, there's a separate pool of cosmetic items available through gameplay only, and nothing gameplay-related can be bought through MTX.

Added November 2023: This year saw updates adding next phase to game's "storyline" and allowing players deeper tinkering with game rules, making it easier or harder as you see fit.

After spending more time in this masterpiece of a game, I come to realize that words can not describe the extent of its beauty to someone who has not felt it before. If you think you might be looking for a game like this, you have found it. Every aspect is polished to the point where you could spend hours living on Sylvia, no matter how you approach it.

And I think that is part of the beauty, the fact that it is, even in survival mode, a sandbox game on the scale of a miniature solar system, to rival the greats, and surpass in my opinion, like Minecraft and Factorio. Do you want exploration? Astroneer has it. Do you want automation? Astroneer has it. Do you want mining, sculpting, completion, lore, multiplayer, all at the same time? Welcome home.

And on the subject of multiplayer, I couldn't imagine a better game to play with friends. And not only that, but it is ridiculously easy to set up, with just 4 inputs, to open up your world to your friends through Steam. Of course, there is the occasional bug, and unpolished item (I'm looking at you, winch), but when encountering them, and this is difficult to explain, truly understand why they are there. You can feel part of the game.
Just like Minecraft commonly is, this game can be a tool for other tasks, like building computers and great monuments to the stars, but in this game, you actually can build to the stars (for practical purposes anyway, there is a hard-to-reach height limit).

And finally, what is the killer for many games, there are no greedy practices by the devs. The most they ask, anywhere in or out of the game, is A: To purchase the soundtrack, which is a work of art in its own right, and B: Cosmetic items, which in no way are essential or affect gameplay, and are very clearly there to support the developers and maybe have some fun in multiplayer.

In summary, this game is the best you will find in the industry, especially with greedy dev practices growing more common. I wish naught but failure to those who might pirate the game like any other, because unlike most, this game deserves to be bought. I thank you for your time reading this.

Very fun and simple game, gorgeous visuals. Your an astronaut trying to find your way back to society, tumbling and collecting along the way you work to build an (overly) simple base. This game is pretty much a sandbox to slowly explore and discover. Astroneer heavily relies on inventory management and puzzle solving, it does get a bit glitchy and every once-in-a-while the puzzle is solved by realizing a button didn't turn on or something simple (Fandom wiki an extreemly useful tool.) The best part of the game to me was having sticky notes with base locations and resource maps all over my monitor. I thoroughly enjoyed this game to the fullest (I feel as dead as finishing a TV show after beating the game, haha..) I suggest you at least give it a try and take it slow, enjoy the crazy colored environment, the wild looking flora, the odd creatures, and have your mind blown at the end. 10/10 game would love a continuation.

It's great, to a point. The early and middle game, when you're slowly scrounging new technology and exploring a new planet, has always been good and slowly became fantastic through the course of several updates over the years. However, ever since the early days there hasn't really been much of a point in continuing on after you've made it off-planet once or twice, and none of the updates have really gotten that down to something truly worth continuing. 

Nevertheless, the earlier stuff can be absolutely magical and worth the price of admission (though maybe on a sale).

Astroneer looks very inviting with it's stylized cartoony looking aesthetic.  However, it is a unwelcoming, non intuitive mess when it comes to actual game play.  Perhaps this is part of the gameplay loop; to have players fiddle with things for a while before they figure out how to do this or that.  If that's what you're looking for in a game, there's plenty of it here.  If the devs ever decide to clean up the tutorial and/or tooltips there's probably at least 20 hours of fun to be had but I got bogged down 7 hours in with what feels like planned opaqueness.
It's just a good game.

Astroneer is...fine for about 20 hours.  You quickly start to realize how shallow and unfun the game is though.

Despite all the interesting logistics/automation tools the game provides, there are no interesting solutions to create.  The game is balanced to be incredibly easy, which means that just doing everything manually is far more optimal.  Even if you do want to explore the automation possibilities, you quickly become totally constrained by the game's mechanics (and not in a fun way).  

Because there is no depth to the crafting/automation content, the "end game" is just slowly driving to a bunch of locations and powering them.  Super exciting.

The game is constantly slightly frustrating due to poor UI, camera controls, vehicle behavior, and essentially every single mechanic.  It's not terrible, but I can't point to a single thing that I feel it did well.

I originally played this back in 2019. At that point I could not recommend it. There were a lot of glitches, optimization issues and frankly not a whole lot to do at that point the game was much more sandbox. A friend and I recently gave this another shot and I am very glad we did. It's a really fun game and I recommend buying at full price.

I love this game!
You can build bases, explore planets, scavenge and build contraptions for what ever your imagination comes up with.
I have built automatic byte farms, Hydrazine factories, alloys factories, sorting machines that can pick up your cargo straight from the tractor when you come back home, a moving train synchronized with the sun to capture light 24/7 and power my base.
The story is great.
Multiplayer is awesome.
I recommend it!

Great game, the only possible complaint I have for it is the fact that ultra-wide aspect ratios (21:9 and 32:9) are not supported at all. I happen to own a 32:9 monitor and trying to play full-screen at native resolution leads to this very zoomed in feeling that makes navigating your backpack and menus very difficult. Either you can't see the item slots/UI or you have to play very zoomed out. Once System Era fixes that though, no problems.

I have enjoyed this game a lot but recently if has been more frustration than fun. Stability of the game seems to be going backwards. One of the big draws of the game, the rovers and vehicles just keep getting worse. During a recent gameplay, it seemed as though I spent more time trying to get rovers un-stuck from flat ground on top of the planet than actually playing... You might get lucky and dig under it a bit and it pops out, but most times nope. You might dig a hole under it until you find a cave and it falls in, then maybe it will be unstuck.. but not always. Ok.. great.. take everything apart, package it all up, haul it 20 feet away, put it all back together and drive off.. 10 mins later it's stuck again. This one is going on the shelf for a while, too many other games I can play without getting frustrated due to bugs.
When you make it past the tutorial this games opens an engaging, fun and very relaxing sandbox environment with, what I assume, a complex and engaging lategame.

Really good game

So you have to go deep into the caves to get some materials. Where you die, because the game's viewing mechanism makes it very hard to see holes in the ground where you fall down to the next level of the caves. Without oxygen. 

There's probably a solution. Haven't found it yet. But, it's still sorta fun. Some day I'll find the umpteen backpacks that I've left lying around. Backpacks that will happily fall down a hill or into a hole, but you can't pick them up to carry them back up.

(edit): mostly solved. Drill can make ramps (LeftCtrl). Just need to have small canister to store the soil required.
An enjoyable game so far.

(edit at 71 hours): Have noticed a number of... issues.

1) Camera is janky as heck, especially if you're near *anything*, or trying to pave+drill at the same time, many times you'll not be seeing anything except the back of your own head or vehicle. 

1a) The lack of first person view, especially when driving/paving/drilling, makes the game insanely annoying at times. I can totally see people quitting the game over it. But I've put enough hours in that I'll probably work through it and try to "finish" the game.   

2) Cannot earn store coin by playing the game, can only purchase with actual money. Not happening, and that they've done this is another point against them.  

3) Can't control paver and drill separately on the front of a large rover. All or nothing. Pity. One wag even recommended having them on opposite ends of the rover, which I found to be a hilariously poor mechanic.

But I've spent my money, so will continue through at least one playthrough. I'm not really seeing the potential for a 2nd one, but the game was cheap enough, and generally fun enough (with some exceptions, see above) that I'll still recommend it. Really wish they had a 1-5 scale instead of a yes/no. Game would get a 3.5 or so.

AAAND rage quit. Stuck on edge of core with large rover. Every time I try to move, the gravity shifts around. Even when I carefully aim AWAY from the core, or at a tangentf, the gravity shifts and flips and generally makes the rover useless. BUT, what makes it REALLY annoying and makes me rage is the LACK OF BLOODY FIRST PERSON VIEW. Instead, every time I get flipped around I can't see anything because I'm close to a wall so I basically go blind. Every time I try to move the rover I can't see because it puts the view BEHIND the thing.  90% of the issue could be resolved if I could SEE. But I can't, because they decided not to allow first person even when every other vision is blocked.

Might come back. Might not. I'm not having fun any more. All because devs were too stubborn to put in a much requested feature, even just for driving.

(after a sleep...) And.. back. Solved the issue. Wasn't at enough of a tangent to the core, and was too close to one of the "strands" that merges with the rock and bends gravity around itself. Still the MOST aggravating thing, all because of devs are stubbornly refusing to put in any first person view.

All that said... yeah, I had some fun. Incredibly frustrating at times, yes, but it can be fun too.

It took me a minute to really like this game as it is a far cry from games I typically play. However, this game is wonderful. You have infinite lives, you have to problem solve to get your stuff back when you die, you get to collect metals and natural resources, avoid being killed by dangerous plants, grow seeds, research tech and then create said tech with the resources you gather. After 31 hours of game play I have finally been able to build a small shuttle and go off planet. It is still fun, it is still an adventure, and it is not over!

Doesn't explain much and it takes a while to get into the flow of things, but when you get going it sucks you in.

Would be nice to cycle through recipes easier (ie. a list rather than one at a time) but otherwise it's fun digging to the centre of a mini planet :P

Also the 4k res doesn't seem like 4k at all!

Title: ASTRONEER: Unearth the Cosmos and Laugh Your Way to the Stars!

Introduction:
Welcome, space pioneers and interstellar explorers! If you've ever dreamt of blasting off to the cosmos, donning an astronaut's helmet, and forging your path among the stars, ASTRONEER is the game that promises to make your dreams come true. But beware, it's not all serious space science here; we're about to take a cosmic rollercoaster ride with a dash of humor!

Graphics: 5/5 - "When Space Looks Like a Whimsical Art Gallery"
Imagine a world where Picasso and Van Gogh decided to team up and paint a galactic masterpiece. That's precisely what ASTRONEER's visuals feel like. The planets are vibrant, the landscapes are surreal, and everything sparkles like a space disco on acid. It's like Salvador Dali and Hubble telescope had a baby, and it's beautiful.

Gameplay: 4/5 - "Making Astronauts Look Like Construction Workers"
In ASTRONEER, you're not just an astronaut; you're a cosmic construction worker. Build bases, extract resources, and shape the terrain as if you're playing with cosmic Play-Doh. The gameplay is as smooth as a moonwalk, but at times, you might feel more like Bob the Builder than Neil Armstrong. Nevertheless, it's a blast to create your own little space empire.

Exploration: 5/5 - "Lost in Space with Style"
ASTRONEER's universe is vast, and it's filled with the wonders of the cosmos. Discover mysterious alien artifacts, uncover hidden secrets, and roam the procedurally generated worlds like a kid in a candy store. And don't forget to bring a friend; exploring these quirky landscapes is even better with company.

Multiplayer: 4/5 - "Space Adventures are Better with Buddies"
ASTRONEER is the best kind of party game—where the party is in space! Team up with your pals to build epic bases, race rovers across the terrain, and embark on hilarious misadventures. Just be ready for the inevitable arguments over who gets to drive the spaceship. Hint: It's always the pilot's call!

Soundtrack: 4/5 - "Space Jam for Your Ears"
The music in ASTRONEER is like an otherworldly jam session. It sets the mood perfectly and keeps you grooving while you build, explore, and conquer the universe. Just remember to turn up the volume when you're about to blast off; your rocket launch deserves an epic soundtrack.

Conclusion:
ASTRONEER isn't just a game; it's a comical, colorful, and creative journey through the cosmos. If you've ever wondered what it's like to be an astronaut with a sense of humor, this game has got you covered. So, buckle up, fellow space cadets, and prepare for a wild ride through the galaxy. And remember, in space, no one can hear you laugh...until now!

I refunded this game back in early access and I admit I never gave it much of a chance. A friend recently talked me into getting it. I decided to stick with it and learn the mechanics seeing how it is out of EA and there isn't much else capturing my interest. I have to say I really love this game and can't believe I ignored it for so long. I do not regret it, though. I got to enjoy as a full game at a time of boredom. 

I was originally turned off by the modular building at first. Something that has since grown on me. I think the biggest turn off for me was at times the camera and the blueprint UI, which wasn't a deal breaker. This feels like a game. What I mean by that is it does not feel cheap like many games do. It is very well thought out. Not many games flow together so nicely with all their mechanics. This is a great example of a passion project. I definitely recommend.

the whole game feels like a giant stim toy and my autistic ass cannot resist

i didn't have the highest hopes getting into this because it seemed so built around multiplayer and kind of smoothed over, but i haven't been able to put it down. collecting and sorting and smelting and automating is just so mesmerizing.
the sound design is a real stand out feature here. everything feels so tactile with its own unique material sound. it feels more like an immersive sandbox toy than a game to me, and i love it

the physics feel rough around the edges. the voxel system is finicky and unfriendly to build with. items are always clipping through the ground into the cave below. you can get stuck in midair from touching a generator at the wrong point. most structures don't have collision. i end up running a meter above the ground sometimes.
but it feels like a toy coming apart in your hands in a way where it's easy to just push whatever separated back together and it's fine. it's never anything irrecoverable.

honestly? this feels like something i could waste a lot of time on. and probably will. and if a stim toy in your computer sounds like your thing then you probably could too.

Vegan Veggie Stew.

4 cups vegetable broth

1 cup water

1/4 cup whole wheat flour

1 small sweet onion, chopped

1 small tomato and/or 1 roasted red pepper, chopped

1/2 cup corn and/or peas

1 cup carrots, diced

3 Tbsp Brewers Yeast/Nutritional Yeast

1 vegan bouillon cube

*Rapunzel brand

1 vegan spicy 'sausage'

*Field Roast Grain Meat Co. Spicy Chipoltle flavor

1 cup mini pasta shells

1 cup mushrooms

1 tsp saffron

2 Tbsp maple syrup

1 cup white or brown rice

4-5 cups purple kale, chopped (about 3/4 of 1 bunch)

2-3 Tbsp EVOO

2 Tbsp Apple Cider Vinegar

2 Tbsp harissa or spicy sun dried tomato spread

1 tsp dried rosemary

2 Tbsp chopped garlic

3 Tbsp soy creamer

1 tsp sea salt

1 Tbsp fresh ground black pepper

optional: diced sweet potato, 3 slices veggie cheese, a few dashes of cayenne

garnish: chiffonaded arugula.

Place soup pot on stove, over high heat. Add 2 Tbsp EVOO, a dash of veggie broth, onions and flour. Whisk quickly to form a roux.

Once you have a thick creamy flour roux, you can add in more ingredients: all the remaining ingredients except the pasta and half of your purple kale. This includes: pepper, sea salt, soy creamer, chopped garlic, dried rosemary (crumble into a powder), harissa, vinegar, remaining EVOO, 2 cups of the purple kale, white rice, saffron, mushrooms, vegan sausage, vegan bouillon cube, water, corn/peas, carrots, nutritional yeast, tomato/pepper and remaining veggie broth. Optional sweet potatoes and veg cheese can go in as well.

Bring soup to a bowl, stir well, cover and reduce heat to a simmer for 20 minutes. This will allow the flavors to merge and the rice to cook.

After the 20 minutes are up, add in the pasta and remaining kale. Cover again and cook on medium heat for ten minutes. You may want to add in another cup of water- only if too much steam has reduced the soup too much.

Do a quick taste test and adjust salt/pepper as needed. Pour steaming hot soup into bowls and garnish with fresh chiffonaded arugula or chopped parsley on top. Side of spelt toast.

[h1][b]Think Satisfactory, No Man's Sky and Starbound, now imagine them [i]together[/i] while still original and surprising. This is ASTRONEER. And it's GORGEOUS.[/b][/h1]
[i]*"Written" in [u]JAN 14 2021[/u] with [u]45.2[/u] hours played. Made minor changes and corrections, 2023, still playing and loving it! One of my favorite games ever since the beginning for sure.[/i]

Firstly, of course I recommend playing it with friends, it's still an experience playing it solo, but it can be even better with friends, great potential there. One of the pros of playing with company is that you'll advance faster and adquire even more resources. 
[i]*Just note that multiplayer can be a little "heavier" to run.[/i] 

I love how there's no pressure on you in this game, it's extremely relaxing and pleasing to play it, the exploration, research and crafting systems only makes it better (among pretty much everything else). You can take your time for literally everything and just chill, no need to rush for anything, simply enjoy the beautiful planets and their varieties as you discover how things work. Talking about it, it's truly an experience to discover how everything works on your own, at certain point you'll need the Astropedia (in-game wiki), highly recommend using it from time to time to remind you how to plan things, which planet to go for (since there's different main resources in each planet, but the basics are shared among all), etc.
 
There's a lot of content and [i]a lot[/i] to discover, so if you don't like exploring the game, maybe that's not for you. Though you can call some friends to do that part while you take care of crafting and base building or something, it's an idea, did it myself some times. It's important to mention it since you'll [i]need[/i] to explore. But don't you worry, because it's so damn pleasing to keep finding more about the planet/moon you're in, marking important spots, getting to know where you are, everything really, it's beyond fun.

You might be lost sometimes, since the game don't give you directions, I personally enjoy that kind of thing in games, it really inspires you to go out and check the universe for yourself, you're meant to explore and test, study everything.
[i]*Friendly reminder of the in-game wiki, it'll always be handy![/i]

Also the progress is [i]so[/i] satisfying, to see you and your "bases" growing both in size and technologically. As you gather and research specific objects you'll find around the planets/moons and their underground, you'll get some kind of research currency called "Bytes", you use them to expand your crafting options along with new technologies. 
[i]*Tip: Don't scan things if you can carry them home to research them in the Research Chamber, that way you'll get more Bytes![/i]

It would be a crime not to compliment the visuals and art overall as well, the entire game is simply gorgeous (as the review states up there), from each planet/moon that really feel different from each other and unique (and believe me they are), to the different machines and suits you can use. They did an amazing work there as well. Also: Space.

I don't enjoy such experience in a really long time, I seriously loved this game, been playing with my partner and it's been perfect, we found another favorite! What a gem. Plus you can play it infinitely, during the quarantine it's been a dreamy experience.

If anything mentioned interests you, go grab this game, you won't regret it. I feel like more people should recognize it and how great it is.

I have two big problems with this game which I discovered after installing it:
1) It has micro-transactions through a predatory store which obfuscates the cost of items with a secondary currency. So you must purchase the secondary in-game currency with real money, and that in-game currency is used to buy the store items to make it much more difficult to understand how much real money you have spent. I will not purchase microtransactions. Whilst I'm fine with a game offering up purely cosmetic items for additional money (this game is offering purely cosmetic items) I object to these predatory tactics. I personally am not okay with micotransactions, and it's particularly galling to see in a game which is clearly geared towards a young target audience. In my opinion it's not responsible or ethical of the game devs to engage in this behaviour. A simple design choice which make this much less egregious would be to at least put an up front real currency price tag on each item.
2) The camera movement makes me feel motion sick. I can't play this game. It is simply unplayable for me. I'm very surprised that in seven years the devs have not yet introduced the simple option of locking the camera to prevent extraneous movement.
I wanted to warn others about the motion sickness, but once I found the microtransaction store

Everything about how this game is played is infuriating.

[b]The UI:[/b]
It appears to be slick and intuitive, until you try to actually use it, then it all falls apart. You grab a resource stack but as you're placing it the camera shifts slightly and instead of placing it on a storage wall/unit/thing you've just dropped it. This is the same for placing buildings and whatnot.

[b]The Camera:[/b]
Oh the camera! Our wonderful view into this little world! If only it could actually be controlled in any meaningful way! For those of us playing with a keyboard and mouse, you have two options.
1. Hold the right mouse button whenever you want to move your view around. If you aren't holding the button, it'll generally, slowly, oh so very slowly, drift towards whatever you're trying to do. You can move your mouse cursor around freely without controlling the camera and do things off to the side of you if you want. If you're like me, or any other sane individual, you probably want the camera to face, you know, what you're actually doing! Which leads nicely into option...
2. Set the camera movement to toggle with the right mouse button, this way you can set it and let it move around wherever you're pointing. Great! Well no, it's not. You see, wherever your mouse cursor is pointed on the screen when you toggle camera movement is where your cursor is going to stay. Did you toggle when your mouse was in the bottom left corner? It's stuck there until you toggle off the camera control. You can easily toggle to where you can't reasonably aim your tools. And it's even worse when you're trying to place objects. Oh and you want to access the stuff on your backpack? Well you have to toggle it off to free up your mouse cursor. So have "fun" with that.

[b]Exploration:[/b]
Exploration problems come down to, well, the camera again, and your character's ability to navigate terrain. The direction your camera faces is NOT the direction your character faces. So if you're in a cave and would like to, oh I don't know, look around and see what's there, or maybe look for how to get out and back to the surface, your camera doesn't control where your flashlight is pointing! Instead of simply looking around, you need to move the camera then move your character, and you better hope you don't walk off a ledge you didn't see because again, you can't really look around with your flashlight. As far as your character's ability to navigate terrain, it seems that they don't very much like walking up any sort of incline. The thing you need to walk up to get out of caves. The thing hills and mountains are made of. I could walk down it, no problem. I could stop and turn while on them, no problem. Can I walk up a gradual incline? It's like walking on ice!

[b]Terra-forming:[/b]
Looks nice in the videos. In reality, the voxels are enormous, and the ability to match elevation is not accurate. It always seems to create slight inclines. And I know my character just can't handle those. Nevermind that other than attempting to make "flat" ground you can't even make smooth ground! Dug down and found a cave? Well the path there is going to be bumpy and you might not be able to jump up the steps you had no choice to make.

[b]Using Structures:[/b]
To use a structure, be that a printer, the mission board(?), your habitat, or anything else I didn't bother attempting to get to before requesting a refund, you need to walk within range, put your mouse cursor over it, and press f. Sounds pretty simple. Well your mouse was one pixel off so instead of selecting the research lab, you've unlocked the platform it's on. Try again. Oh! Close again, but your camera was unlocked and it decided to move when you pressed the button.

[b]Instructions:[/b]
The tasks you need to do don't really give you any direction. "Research and apply a drilling attachment to your tool." Okay, I've never done that before in this game, how do I research? "Collect 4 of [resource]." I don't know what that is, nor do I know how to collect anything yet, maybe a short tutorial screen would be nice.

[b]Forum Nonsense:[/b]
Nearly every problem this game has comes down to the decision to make it third-person. People on forums say the devs did it that way to set it apart, and that, "it's actually very intuitive. You see, in real life you'd be grabbing stuff from your backpack to put into the printers." First of all, this isn't real life. Secondly, when I take something out of a bag and put it on a table, I can turn my head without moving my hand. I don't suddenly miss the table. Also, how is having to pull up the backpack to move items around any different from a standard inventory menu? And lastly, if your argument really is that it's like real life then why the hell is it in third person?

[b]Fixes:[/b]
The camera, handling items, and using structures, would be fixed if it was in first person, you're aiming where you're looking and you're looking where you're aiming. Fixing walking up inclines is solved by doing it the way hundreds, if not thousands, of other games have done it. Heck, making a character walk up an incline was done better on the N64 and PS1! Instructions and tutorial moments are part of making a video game accessible. Greater options for terra-forming would go a long way. And the backpack just being a simple menu instead of this drag-and-drop items thing would make actually using it so much cleaner.

[b]Closing Remarks:[/b]
Overall, it's just a big case of form over function. And I want to play a game, not fight a game.

This game scratches an itch that no other game of its kind ever has. It fills a perfect niche of complexity where it's not so simple that it's boring and not so complicated that it makes you want to give up. All of the game's core mechanics are so perfectly designed to be simple, yet leave so much room for player innovation. It is a LOT deeper than it seems on the surface; arguably the best part of this game is figuring out all the clever tricks you can do with the automation and storage systems. Speaking of which, they are incredibly fun to optimize. There are no "containers" in this game, just shallow holes in various buildings that items slot into like lego pieces. Figuring out the best ways to manipulate this system into giving you the most storage for the least space is just one of the many ingenious systems that rewards players for experimentation and optimization. Explaining exactly why this game is fun is difficult to do; it's something you kind of have to experience for yourself. I find myself coming back to Astroneer every few months just for the pleasure of immersing myself into the gameplay loop yet again. Easily a 9.5/10, a true hidden gem.

Its a cool game but basebuilding in this game is complete ass.

First, you need a platform for your machines to work, which means a lot of grinding just to have every single one of them sit on an otherwise useless item. With all the machines you'll need, and maybe a few autoarms, thats an easy 30-60 platforms

Second, forming terrain for your machines to sit on is a NIGHTMARE
By default your terrain tool can 'flatten' terrain, except its not actually going to be flat because of rounding errors, which is going to make it impossible to not put random bumps into your surface
Then this is further complicated by the fact that there is a mod that aligns your flatten tool to the curvature of the planet, or so it says, but it doesnt work and it just creates random elevations of terrain everywhere, creating even more and more pronounced bumps.
Then you try the 'levelling block' the game has, and you'll immediately realize that the block that's supposed to create actually flat surfaces, can only do so around gateways, which make it impractical for you to build around them because of how much space they take up and if you flatten the terrain around them, then your surface is going to be hanging 15 meters in the air and getting up there with land-based vehicles is going to be ass
Maybe you arent an ass about having an actually flat surface, i'd be willing to settle for a surface free of bumps that curves according to the planet, but i cant do that because the alignment tool mod is jank and wont actually align it properly

This game is also obscenely grindy with the amount you'll need just to finish the game, and both inventory management, and base management with the layout of the things is stupid.

Oh, and they have an expensive as hell microtransaction shop in a singleplayer/coop game. Absolutely disgusting.

I recommend the game if you can get over these things, but the not recommended is just out of spite, because why the fuck is it so fucking hard to just let us make smooth surfaces?!

This is one of the worst survival craft games i've ever played.

THE clunkiest UI in probably any game EVER. 
Inventory management on the actual 3d backpack on your character? Yeah, good luck dragging all the items and tool upgrades between the slots on an in-game 3d object when you're trying to get stuff off your corpse.
Research menu on some weird grid on a cylinder? Ooof, good luck trying to find the one thing you need to research amoung 100 other things, by rotating through each column and row, one by one, like with some sort of a wheel cypher.
Crafting menu on your character only navigatable by clicking through left/right arrow buttons on the UI screen? (Not even the left/right buttons on the keyboard!) Good luck going through a list of 30 things when trying to find the one you need.

And the gameplay is no better.
The only way to kill a hostile thing - is to dig a hole under it.
The only way to gather a resource - is to dig a hole under it.
One tool for every job, and this tool just digs holes. And then you keep falling into the holes you yourself made, and keep dying from lack of oxygen because you tried to dig yourself out and instead fell into an even deeper hole that happened to be under your hole. What a !@#$hole.

What about building/crafting? Everything you build has to sit on its own platform. Need a printer? Print a platform first. Need a forge? Print another platform. Need a reasearch station? Print another platform. Before you know it - your base is just a gigantic messy cluster field of platforms and electrical cables between them.
The only real challenge is having oxygen supply. THIS game should have been called "oxygen not included".

Maybe you'd love it if you were 10 years old and just wanted to dig holes everywhere. Otherwise - stick to survival craft games that are actually worthwhile... Like... Subnautica, Valheim, 7 Days to Die, Raft, Medieval Dynasty, Don't Starve, Minecraft, Terraria, Starbound... I can keep going, because almost anything is better than this.

Fun, lighthearted game with tons of replayability. Highly recommend for those who like base building, resource gathering, exploration, and automation.
Performance wise, the game runs great, and you only start running into issues when you blow tons of things up at once.
The game mechanics are great, and you can customize pretty much every control. There are some weird things with the camera sometimes, but it's not bad and won't hinder the gameplay experience.
Lore wise, there's an overall storyline and an endgame goal(s), but it's not the focus of the game and so there's not much depth to it. If you want a lore heavy game, this isn't really for you.
Multiplayer is great, and imo it enhances the experience of the game.

[h1]--------------------------------------------------------------- [/h1]
[b]Second Review - 2021[/b]

I like this game, and I like the progress that the creators are making. The game is relaxing. The developers really listen to their players and fix bugs in the game, accept ideas. Three years ago, I asked them to add enemies to make the game a little more interesting, and they did. Unfortunately, I have more games offline than online, I have no friends who play this game, but that doesn't stop me from loving it. I'm glad they added an option for dedicated servers; I slowed down slightly with this, but it better late than never. 
What made a negative impression on me was the store they created. The idea of virtual currency and items bought with real money is a normal practice for any company, which is completely understandable. The problem with everyone is that they make their virtual currency too expensive and some items. I would be happy if the developers focus on paid items as long as they do not exceed the game's price. In my opinion, if the prices are reduced by at least 10-12%, there will be people who will contribute even more with funds!
[b]Dear creators of Astronneer, there are so many options for displaying a list of servers; please add it to the menu. Why should we look for a server on the Internet when it can be registered and displayed in a list as in most old games? [/b] 
- Thank you so much!

There's just too many other games out that will offer a more enjoyable experience.

Complexity of Factorio with none of the depth. Survival mechanics of Subnautica, with none of the challenge. For all it's beauty – there is barely any game here. It's just one fetch quest after an other without even the decency to add a zombie or two.

There are only three ways the player can die – falling damage (extremely buggy), running out of oxygen or getting hit twice by a hostile plant (which don't move and are out-ranged by the player). Getting into a vehicle makes you immune to all three and also saves the game.

Players in the community seem to keep focusing on efficiency, but this is a casual game with no loss condition. This isn't Factorio, where being inefficient leads to getting mobbed by environmentalist natives. Worst thing that can happen to you in this game is dying while running back to your corpse, but even then – that doesn't despawn your dropped gear – it just causes the map marker to vanish.

Half the game is wrangling with the terrible floaty third person MMO-type camera in extremely narrow spaces, where your character takes up the entire screen, hoping to escape to a wider area before you run out of oxygen.

The inventory system is interesting, but it takes way too many clicks to do what you want to do, making it inferior to just a simple crafting sheet. Crafting from the inventory is a particular note of complaint, because every time you click "next" and land on a recipe you have resources for, they get automatically swapped out of your pack/utility/tool slots, messing up the established order.

Items often glitch through the ground. It's especially bad if the game's running at higher FPS. Even vehicles are subject to this.

The soundtrack is unexceptional and uninspired.

The best part of the game are the singing pet snails, but they also give overpowered buffs to the player if fed. The buffs include infinite oxygen and invincibility, and last ten to thirty minutes. The food is also easy to get – they eat any plant you come across.

Overall, a brainless pseudo-logistics sandbox without any leviathans. Fun enough to mess around in when stressed, but will also bore in the long run. At least a third of my playtime was literally being asleep at the keyboard.

Astroneer: A Disappointing Journey

I first ventured into Astroneer's world during its alpha stage, and I was captivated by the promise it held. However, as time went on, I found myself increasingly let down.

The game I initially fell in love with has transformed into a buggy mess. Oddly enough, it seemed to have fewer bugs during its alpha phase. To make matters worse, many features that made the game enjoyable were removed, and microtransactions were introduced.

I must admit, I'm one of those 'cry babies' who strongly dislikes microtransactions when they are essentially abandoning content for the game. In my opinion, this game had already generated enough revenue to avoid such practices. It's disheartening to see a game with so much potential take this route.

While some argue that microtransactions are necessary to support ongoing development, Astroneer is rarely updated with new features. So, the argument that they 'need it to update the game' or 'to support themselves' doesn't hold much weight here.

I genuinely loved and enjoyed Astroneer in its early days, but sadly, it now resides in my pile of uninstalled games, unlikely to be played again. I'd rate it a 5/10, mainly because the developers seemed to turn their back on the community, leaving numerous bugs unresolved and resorting to questionable practices.

Very cool mining and crafting game, with modular assemble/disassemble mechanics similar to Legos.
Graphics are simplistic, yet cute. Gameplay is interesting, exciting and addicting.
I must admit I was a bit skeptical at first and I've had this in my library for years, until recently I gave it a try. Wow, this game did not disappoint! Highly recommended!

GOOD
- Digging for resources is satisfying, and it goes deep!
- Crafting is done through the use of printers. Interesting game mechanic.
- Modularity of the equipment is so cool. It's kinda like Legos.
- Automation systems gives lots of possibilities.
- Planets are really round. If you walk/drive in one direction, you will eventually come back to where you started. They are decent size btw.
- Travel between planets.
- Several types of vehicles, incl. a train.
- You can now start a custom game with your own planets.

BAD
- Planets are fairly empty and lifeless. Could really need some wildlife, more things to explore, more threats/challenges, etc. This is my biggest complaint. Gameplay gets a bit stale after 50+ hours.
- Camera angle can be quite clunky, especially in caves or near other objects. I wish there was an option for 1st person view.
- UI is not the best, could definitely need some improvements.
- Platforms locks/unlocks with one touch of a button. Very easy to accidently unlock.
- [spoiler] Pets are way too OP. It ruins the balance of the game. Pets as just pure companions would be much better. [/spoiler]

Astroneer is a sandbox exploration and construction game set in a procedurally generated universe. Players take on the role of an astronaut who must explore and collect resources to survive and thrive on alien planets. The game features a variety of tools and vehicles that can be used to build bases, vehicles, and other structures. Players can also explore caves, underwater areas, and other hidden places to find new resources and challenges.

Pros:

Relaxing and creative gameplay
Beautiful and varied environments
Lots of content to explore and discover
Easy to learn but difficult to master
Great for solo or multiplayer play
Cons:

Can be repetitive at times
Some technical issues
Lack of a clear story or objective
Overall, Astroneer is a great game for players who enjoy exploration, crafting, and building. It's a relaxing and creative experience that can be enjoyed solo or with friends.

Here are some specific things that I liked about Astroneer:

The gameplay is very relaxing and creative. There is no pressure to do anything in particular, and you can just explore and build whatever you want.
The environments are beautiful and varied. There are a variety of planets to explore, each with its own unique look and feel.
There is a lot of content to explore and discover. There are over 100 resources to collect, and many different items to craft.
The game is easy to learn but difficult to master. There is a lot of depth to the crafting system, and it can be challenging to build the most efficient and effective structures.
The game is great for solo or multiplayer play. You can explore the universe on your own, or team up with friends to build bases and explore together.
Here are some specific things that I didn't like about Astroneer:

The game can be repetitive at times. There are a limited number of things to do, and you may find yourself doing the same things over and over again.
There are some technical issues. The game can be buggy at times, and there have been reports of crashes.
The game lacks a clear story or objective. There is no real goal to the game, and you are left to your own devices to figure out what to do.
Overall, Astroneer is a great game with a lot to offer. It's a relaxing and creative experience that can be enjoyed solo or with friends. However, the game can be repetitive at times, and there are some technical issues. If you are looking for a game with a clear story or objective, then Astroneer may not be the best choice for you. However, if you are looking for a game that allows you to explore, craft, and build at your own pace, then Astroneer is a great option.

Rating: ★★★★★
Space Madness: Where Friends Become Frenemies
Astroneer is the game that took my friendships to new, interstellar heights! After 37 hours of playing with "the boys," I can confidently say that this game is a delightful mix of teamwork, chaos, and accidental rocket launches.

Pros:

Endless Laughs: Astroneer turns grown adults into giggling school kids. Whether you're accidentally launching your buddy into orbit or suffocating because you forgot to bring oxygen, you'll be laughing so hard you'll wonder if you've been hit by a laughing gas meteorite.

Base Building Bonanza: You can build bases on alien planets, and it's like playing with intergalactic LEGO sets. Just remember to check with your buddies before you expand the base into their personal space or bury their rovers in a mountain of dirt.

Resource Hunting Shenanigans: The hunt for resources can be an adventure. You'll be digging deep, chasing elusive resources, and yelling at your friends to stop stealing your precious, hard-earned stuff!

Cons:

Resource Mismanagement: Expect your teammates to "borrow" your stuff without asking, leading to disputes fiercer than who gets the last slice of pizza.

Rover Racing Fiascos: Ever wanted to race rovers on an alien planet? Well, you'll quickly learn that it's a terrible idea. Your once-beloved vehicle will turn into a runaway lawnmower, causing havoc and hilarity.

The Great Oxygen Conspiracy: Accidentally running out of oxygen while exploring the deep caves is a rite of passage. You'll learn to appreciate the sound of heavy breathing more than ever before.

In summary, Astroneer is the perfect game for friends who want to test the limits of their friendships and space exploration skills. Whether you're constructing elaborate bases, engaging in epic resource battles, or just trying to survive the harsh alien landscapes, this game guarantees unforgettable adventures and non-stop laughter. Just remember to bring your sense of humor along for the ride, and may the oxygen be forever in your favor!

YEARS LATER UPDATE: I started playing this game when it was in early access and have come back to it several times since then, most recently in the last few weeks. The devs have added a ton of depth to the game relative to how it used to play, while maintaining the charming atmosphere and without putting too much pressure on the player to get super deep in the nitty gritty. I got all the achievements and 100%'d the game outside of hardcore mode and had a blast doing it!

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ORIGINAL REVIEW: 
----------
ASTRONEER is not the biggest and most impressive game that you're going to play in your life. 

Great, now that that's out of the way, I can tell you that despite my statement above, I believe ASTRONEER to be one of my favorite games of all time. There are few games I have played that have such wonderful atmosphere. It's one of those games that does offer hardships, but no matter what it just makes you happy to play it (only other game I can think of that gives similar feelings is Stardew Valley). I've had this game for quite awhile now, and I've been following the progress through early access to 1.0 which dropped list night. At first, the game was beautiful and fun but buggy and somewhat scarce where content was concerned. People voiced those concerns and guess what? The devs listened! They have put in a lot of hard work on a game I can tell they really love and believe in, end the results soak for themselves. If you're looking for an incredibly fun, co-operative, low-stress and entertaining space-sim/sandbox game, look no further! 

Devs I'm not sure if you guys read all of these reviews, but I just want you to know how gratifying and refreshing it is to have a team of developers who seem like they're totally in love with the game they're making, and who follow up on the promises they make. I really appreciate all the work you guys have put in, and just wanted you to know that I think you've made a really wonderful game. Thank you!

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[h1] Worth The Price? 10/10 [/h1]
A very chill sandbox game that takes you to different planets to unlock more and better devices. It is the go to game when I want to relax while colonizing planets. This game is still slowly being updated with new content, so I always like to come back occasionally and check it out.

[h1] Replayability? 9/10 [/h1]
It's a sandbox game, so it all depends on how much you are willing to do with what the developers gave you. This game offer a good amount of freedom to express your creativity using automated devices and modulated vehicles. I restarted world at least 10+ times and still feel very fresh.

It is still updating, so I often come back to check them out.

[h1] Gameplay? 10/10 [/h1]
The progression system isn't too grindy or complex. The most complex recipes can be made simpler by a good automation system.

Some planning and counting are required playing this game, or you will be annoyed you will have to waste fuel flying back to grab one more resource.

[h1] Story? 3/10 [/h1]
Have minor final objectives and lore, but not important for a sandbox game.

[h1] Visual? 10/10 [/h1]
It has a very creative visual that is simplistic and calming to look at. The musics are also very fitting of the vibe too.

Normally, i would just write a 1 to 10 score review for a game. However, for Astroneer, i want to do something special.
I have been following this game since early access, and i have a lot to say about it. Thankfully, most of it is positive.
This is a very unique game. I have seen only a small handful of games that have the low-poly terrain structure that Astroneer has. It feels like you are inside of the imaginative space universe of a child when playing this game. Once again, a very unique feel. But i can't just list the uniqueness of a game forever. There are many other aspects, such as the very calm play style, and the greatness of multiplayer. I can't really further describe how good this game is. The only way to find out, is to play it yourself. I am aware that Astroneer currently costs 30$, but i have seen it go on sale before. This is 100% also a game to buy a friend a copy of as well.

Game desperately needs better gamepad controls and  an actual tutorial.  Controls are very, very non-intuitive.  I'd give that a pass if it had a decent tutorial to get you up to speed, though.  Instead, what you get is essentially a list of goals and a set of Ikea-like instructions for how the game works.  So you go to your mission computer and it has a rewards entry saying you've been awarded an oxygenator and printer and then a mission of unpacking it.  I've no idea what an oxygenator looks like or whether the doors on the capsule you've just landed in can be opened to unpack things.  First 20 minutes were spent looking around for what I was supposed to hook up only to find that you have to accept a reward for having landed, which then beams the oxygenator in.  There's a page halfway into the instruction manual that says you have to click to get the reward but who thinks to go to the instructions for literally the first step of the game?  Wouldn't it have been pretty easy to just say "Click x to collect reward" on the rewards screen?  The rest of my time so far has been trying to figure out the mess of controls from goal prompts like "Fill container with Soil": Try sucking up soil with the gun, that doesn't do it.  Do I have to get more soil?  Do I have to hook up the container I picked up somehow?  Do I have to change a setting on the gun? No idea and the manual doesn't help.  I know there's tons of Beginner vids people have made online and I could get answers from them.  But if you need to watch third-party online tutorials just to get a handle on the basic controls of the game, there's a problem.

Don't buy the game if you really hate game-breaking/game-changing bugs, lack of sensible content, and getting frustrated on steep learning curves. Otherwise... Extremely fun, but hard to leave a positive review due to the issues described below.

----

Oh my god, oh my god, I want to be able to give this game a positive review. I wish I could... But I can't, and here's why.

Don't get me wrong. I love the game. I love the concept. It's really fun to play. But...

The game has been in early access since 2016 and was fully released in 2019. It's now 2023 and holy cow are there still bugs that I know have been there since day 1 (some reddit that has researched how to fix most of them will give you that info) and the devs seem to be completely neglecting it.

Super buggy. I'm talking SUPER buggy. To the point where the game can literally break and cause you to lose your mind. Here are just a few of the things my boyfriend and I encountered while playing together (as only 2 people)...

1.) He couldn't even play the game to begin with on the first install. There was an infinite loading screen issue that took us 2-3 hours to figure out how to fix the issue that required changing the game files. This has been a known issue since the release of the game and it still happens...

2.) Abundant sound, light and camera malfunctions

3.) "Losing" objects into the underground space (for example, placing an object on the ground and it sinks into the ground and is permanently lost).

4.) Bf was using a tractor + trailor when he was randomly launched into the air (almost into space), the tractor + trailor disappeared and landed on the other side of the planet and died and could not recover his belongings.

5.) Lots of visual glitches (for example, one of the thrusters of each other's rocket is constantly spewing fire, an enemy facility is there for one person and not for the other but still kills both people).

6.) Automatic collectors that collect things from a node where it is not placed directly (for example, the resource node from copper and resin was found and collected only resin).

7.) After activating a door, our characters start randomly scrolling (on each other's screen, but not on our own screen) and we die for some unknown reason.

8.) There are numerous performance issues on both our sides. He has a ~10 year old top-of-the-line hardware, while I have a ~2 year old top-of-the-line computer, and we both have similar issues. To solve this, we both need to turn off his fps at 60 while we both need to turn down a lot of graphics attributes and rendering attributes for the game to run properly, and I need to turn off my fps indefinitely (otherwise I get really bad FPS drops and vice versa...).

9.) Forget about using this with a controller... even though it has controller support...

10.) Automated stuff that blocks other stuff... (for example, we had a centrifuge on a platform next to the research labs. Clay nuggets were automatically placed in the research labs and could not be removed). This would be a loooot literally to everything and everything.

And soooo much more... Honestly, I'd be here forever to explain everything. Also keep in mind that the more people you play with, the more bugs increase 10x each time, and just playing by yourself has bugs like crazy.

Overall the game content is quite plentiful and quite nice, but there are some serious quality issues with this game that disappointed me, which are worth pointing out...

1.) The beginning is rough. There is very little explanation of what to do or how to use the game's controls or literally what you are doing there, why you are doing it, etc. I'm not for hand holding games but this game is definitely something else.

2.) Feels... Incomplete? I can't say for sure as I'm not 100% complete with everything (we're quite a distance away though!), but there are many things that make me go "Hmmm"... Why didn't the developers include this?" (e.g. more lore and handling for lore-based objects with 0 purpose or more underlying creation logic/elements).

3.) There can be no real automation masterpieces in this game. Unless I'm missing something, there are a lot of limitations on how you can automate your bases and resource gathering which is a bit frustrating.

4.) The flow of missions feels very clunky - it just feels like random ideas from the developers that were shoved into the game.

5.) Again... there are a lot of vague things in the lore.

6.) A lot of things are mislabelled, which kind of makes a difference, especially when looking for resources (for example, one planet had a resource 'in the mountains', but there were no 'mountains' on that planet).

7.) Camera control is a nightmare to learn and I still struggle with it.

And of course, there is much more in this respect too.


But yeah... I'll still play it because I want to finish it and I've paid for it, but that's something else.

In the boundless expanse of space, where the cosmos unfolds its secrets and challenges, lies a realm of daring exploration and limitless possibility. Welcome to the mesmerizing world of Astroneer, a game that beckons adventurers to embark on an interstellar odyssey like no other.

 As the celestial curtain rises, you find yourself standing on an alien planet, its landscapes both awe-inspiring and mysterious. Towering mountains composed of iridescent crystals pierce the horizon, while luminescent flora cast an otherworldly glow across the untamed terrain. The very air crackles with a palpable sense of anticipation, daring you to venture forth and unravel the enigmas that lie hidden beneath the surface. 

Armed with your trusty astral suit and a multifunctional tool, you take your first steps onto this uncharted realm. The atmosphere hums with a blend of both trepidation and excitement, for every decision you make, every resource you gather, shapes the destiny of your voyage. The terrain manipulator in your hand becomes a beacon of progress, allowing you to sculpt the land itself to suit your needs. With every dig, carve, and reshape, you unearth a symphony of minerals – from precious ores that glimmer like stardust to exotic elements that promise untold power.

 Yet, as with any grand endeavor, challenges and mysteries abound. The very ground beneath your feet quakes, revealing underground networks of caves and tunnels teeming with danger and intrigue. The harsh elements of the alien world test your survival instincts, pushing you to adapt, to improvise, and to conquer. Mighty storms, both beautiful and terrifying, sweep across the landscape, challenging your ability to weather the cosmic tempests. 

But you are not alone in this cosmic ballet. Friends and fellow explorers, near and far, journey beside you, their astral suits glinting in the distant horizon. Collaboration becomes the key to unlocking the universe's deepest secrets. In your shared quest, you traverse the planets, each with its own breathtaking vistas and unique challenges – from desolate moons draped in ethereal light to verdant landscapes teeming with flora that pulse with life.

 The allure of discovery is matched only by the promise of innovation. As you unravel the planet's mysteries, you unearth blueprints for wondrous contraptions and vehicles, each offering a new perspective on the cosmos. The journey to the stars becomes a symphony of engineering, as you construct intricate bases that stretch their metallic arms toward the heavens, establishing beacons of humanity's indomitable spirit against the celestial backdrop.

 Astroneer is more than a game; it's an invitation to become an interstellar pioneer, a dance with the cosmos that blends breathtaking beauty with heart-pounding challenges. It's a tale of exploration, survival, and the unquenchable desire to reach beyond the stars. So, don your astral suit, wield your trusty tool, and step onto the alien stage. Your destiny among the stars awaits, and the universe is yours to shape, explore, and conquer.

And with that, saves. You need to go in a shuttle, shelter or vehicle to save your progress. And that is something I don't do often after obtaining the portable oxygenator. I'm not close to any of those. When I pick up the extractor.. Half an hour of work dries out.

I'm not saying that saves are done wrong in this game, to the opposite. I think it's a nice detail, but it would be nice if every once in a while we had a backup when we're near to one of those things, or just idle..

ASTRONEER has taken me on an unforgettable journey through the cosmos. From the moment I landed on my first alien planet, I was captivated by the sense of wonder and discovery that the game offers. The vibrant landscapes, the sense of solitude, and the mysteries waiting to be unraveled make every step an adventure.

The game's sandbox nature lets me shape the world around me, creating bases, vehicles, and structures as I see fit. The satisfaction of gathering resources and using them to build and expand my base is incredibly rewarding. ASTRONEER's crafting and building mechanics are intuitive, allowing me to focus on exploring and creating without unnecessary complications.

What truly sets ASTRONEER apart is its unique art style and calming atmosphere. The serene vistas and the minimalist design create an ambiance that is both relaxing and inviting. It's a game that I find myself returning to when I need to unwind and escape from the hustle and bustle of everyday life.

Whether I'm playing solo or exploring with friends, ASTRONEER always manages to spark my imagination and fuel my sense of curiosity. The updates and additions from the developers keep the experience fresh, ensuring that there's always something new to discover.

If you're looking for a game that lets you forge your own path among the stars and provides a peaceful yet engaging experience, ASTRONEER is an absolute gem that I wholeheartedly recommend
