[h1]ASTRONEER [/h1]
In the vast universe of gaming, few titles manage to capture the spirit of exploration, creativity, and cooperation as effectively as ASTRONEER. Developed by System Era Softworks, ASTRONEER presents a mesmerizing sandbox adventure that invites players to embark on an interplanetary journey filled with wonder, challenges, and limitless possibilities.

[b] Unparalleled Exploration: [/b]
ASTRONEER's greatest strength lies in its ability to foster a deep sense of exploration. The game's diverse and procedurally generated planets are a playground for discovery, each offering unique landscapes, resources, and mysteries to uncover. Whether you're spelunking through intricate cave systems, scaling towering mountains, or traversing vast deserts, every step in ASTRONEER's world is a chance to stumble upon something new and intriguing.

[b] Creative Base Building: [/b]
At the core of ASTRONEER is the art of base building. The game provides players with a wide array of modules and tools to design and construct their very own interplanetary bases. The modular nature of the construction system encourages creativity, allowing players to customize their bases to match their preferences and adapt to the challenges of each planet. From efficient power generation to resource refinement, the satisfaction of watching your base grow and thrive is immeasurable.

[b] Resource Gathering and Management: [/b]
Resource gathering forms the backbone of ASTRONEER's gameplay. The thrill of unearthing rare minerals and harnessing them to expand your base and create new technologies is a driving force that keeps players engaged. The game's resource management mechanics add depth to the experience, as you'll need to strategize and prioritize which materials to gather and how to utilize them effectively. This aspect of the game fosters a rewarding sense of progression as you unlock new technologies and capabilities.

[b] Cooperative Multiplayer: [/b]
While ASTRONEER can be enjoyed in solo play, its cooperative multiplayer mode takes the experience to another level. Joining forces with friends to explore and build together enhances the gameplay's social and collaborative aspects. The synergy of combining each player's expertise and creativity can lead to awe-inspiring bases and expeditions that are far more ambitious and enjoyable than what you could achieve alone.

[b] Charming Aesthetic: [/b]
Visual design plays a crucial role in making ASTRONEER an enchanting experience. The game boasts a delightful, low-poly art style that's not only visually pleasing but also contributes to the sense of wonder and discovery. The planets' vibrant colors and distinct biomes make each new location feel like a painting waiting to be explored.

[b] Regular Updates and Community Engagement: [/b]
One of the hallmarks of a successful game is the ongoing support from its developers. System Era Softworks has demonstrated a commendable commitment to ASTRONEER through regular updates, bug fixes, and new content releases. The developers also maintain open communication with the player community, actively seeking feedback and ideas to further enrich the game's experience. This dedication to improvement ensures that ASTRONEER remains a relevant and enjoyable title long after its initial release.

In conclusion, ASTRONEER is a captivating journey into the realms of exploration, creativity, and collaboration. Its unique blend of open-world exploration, base building, resource management, and cooperative gameplay creates an experience that's as rewarding as it is enchanting. Whether you're a solo gamer yearning for a universe to uncover or a group of friends seeking to forge a new frontier together, ASTRONEER promises an adventure that will leave you starry-eyed and eager to explore the cosmos. With its constantly evolving universe and dedicated development team, this game is a shining example of the potential of modern gaming to inspire and captivate players of all kinds.

I have chosen to write this review now that I have finished experiencing most of (like 90% I think) this game has to offer and earning every steam achievement.
This is a good example of what early access games should strive to be, building upon the ideas and concepts along the way until it's a functional released game and barely recognizable to those who last played it in its early stages. It's a neat little game where you run around and build upon your base by getting more and more resources by pushing further and further out of your oxygenated safe zone. 
Along with Subnautica, this was one of the first games (and the 2nd of two early access games) I've ever played on my PC. I've been around since the days when the hissbines looked like weird cauldrons with glowing green stuff inside, the cables were thick pipes, and sand/duststorms raged across the planets. While it has its bugs and glitches, it's a very solid experience you can pour countless hours into, since each planet has something you need to do there. However, I will say that Vesania (OGs know it as exotic) is still lacking, since every resource you can get there is easier to obtain elsewhere. The new(ish) mission log is definitely a good addition, giving those who aren't ancient veterans a decent idea of what they ought to do next, and providing incentives for doing the things they should be doing anyway. 
I do wish there were improvements for your backpack, since you're limited on space later into the game when you're carrying pretty necessary equipment with you at all times. The same goes for the Shuttles. 
I also wish I could access the older versions through the steam properties tool, to both compare the game in the beginning to how it is now and show my friends who helped me 100% the game.
I watched the min-documentary on youtube when the game officially released in 2019 (R.I.P. Paul). At the time I got my PC and this game I had no idea what happened and what was happening to the game's team. I wish nothing but the best for this game and the talented people behind it.

Played solo, hadn't played this game for over a year. 

Gameplay loop was boring: find materials to craft oxygen poles to gather more materials to craft more objects.

Player progression: 1) advanced items were in the list of early-game unlockables, which added to the overwhelming amount of options and made it more difficult to understand the crafting system and progress through it as searching for rare materials without knowing they were rare lead to confusion in how to find them. 2) The UI was poorly designed, it separated crafting information into multiple tabs and menus, most of which were displayed on a small in-game digital encyclopedia with low contrast between the text and background

Notes:
1) The crafting system should've organized it's unlockables into simpler tech trees the started with the simplest objects to build, the easiest materials to find and the most important for player progression

2) Astroneer's gameplay should've been much less sub-terrainian: Astroneer's space-exploration theme felt poorly done as gameplay was mostly mining underground in dark caves; it's concept would have worked better if it were either a horror game or something more like deep rock galactic
3) I didn't enjoy the game feel, especially the effects of items attaching to sockets, those felt like poor imitations of nintendo or lego games.

Astroneer strikes the perfect balance of light automation, exploration, and chilling to create a meditative experience.

Astroneer hits the perfect balance of base-building, relaxation, and survival. I'm the type of person who will turn off hunger and thirst in survival games if possible and if the game can still be a challenge without those stressors always on your mind (like Subnautica). Was very happy to see that the only needed resource to survive is oxygen - mixed with the ability to avoid a few hostile plants and not fall to your death off a cliff/crevasse.

Where you begin with just an empty backpack and a shelter, eventually you will be flying around with jetpacks, you will be able to survive without oxygen tethers with a portable oxygenator, and you can maintain power in your backpack with a QT-RTG that provides unlimited power (eat your heart out, Palpatine). All of this makes exploration, completing your goals, and finding rare resources a lot easier. It takes a few hours of gameplay to hit that self-sustaining point, but damn, the feeling is so rewarding when you get there.

There is a very light story involved, and most of the time I saw it more as mission-to-mission instead of seeing an over-arcing grand plan. And I like it even more for that! You can approach missions in any order you want (lightly funneled through various technology tiers and unlocks) or just say "screw it" to any story and build the system you want. My friend and I had a blast (yes, co-op multiplayer!) getting our base as automated as possible, and no mission really makes you do that.

Overall, I recommend Astroneer.  It's worth the full price; definitely get it if it's on sale.  It is a truly relaxing and rewarding experience, both solo and co-op. The only points of frustration were if I happened to die very far away from my base while carrying valuable or rare resources. But even then, you can find your death site to reclaim the resources, and you'll learn to find ways to avoid dying (mostly).

Pro tip: Do NOT try putting Dynamite in the Smelter. Or do. Your call. :)

Astroneer: a great game but still with some annoying and serious bugs. 

It is a difficult game to describe being part survival and part exploration and entirely sandbox. There is a great deal of fun and satisfaction in building your base and then reaching other planets and exploring - and constructing bases - there as well. However, base building is limited to just putting together machines outside, constructing any sort of building for your machines is exceptionally hard. Missions are a nice addition both to guide you initially and to provide something to do later in the game. 

While it is still a lot of fun and there is plenty to do the game still feels incomplete despite no longer being early access. There are various types of mysterious objects lying around that have no discernible use but are clearly there for some reason - either something that is intended to come later or an ideal that was scrubbed without removing the objects.

Building on this feeling of incompleteness is the fact that there are still serious bugs with objects falling through the terrain. This seems now limited to areas where you have filled in yourself but it is beyond frustrating to have important resource canisters or storage modules just disappear from your base by falling into the caves below. Finding them can be hard to impossible and sometimes entire rovers of equipment and resources can just disappear. This has been a long standing bug and really should have been fixed by now given how frustrating it is and you cannot undo the effects of the bugs using creative mode since this blocks all achievements forever in the save which is understandable but they might want to say that BEFORE you click on it (it is very simple to do) on rather than afterwards!

Still, overall it is a fun game but the continuing serious bugs limit your fun.

It's not ready*. Check back once it's out of Early Access. Interface is opaque, basic resources are hard to find, radius on tethers is comically low (it takes 2 packs of tethers to go more than 20 steps from the landing pod), the mission structure is frankly bizarre -- after a fairly short time you get a mission that's 'unlock smelting then smelt aluminum' with no guidance about what the unlock requirements are or where aluminum might be found, so you're just wandering around your pitifully tiny oxygen radius vacuuming up planet in your boring terraform vacuum looking for aluminum that you can't smelt because you can't unlock anything (because nobody is telling you how). Base building is completely unexplained, everything has to plug into a platform (the game does not tell you this, you just kind of have to know), and there's no way to rotate things before placing them. In a game where power cords have a fixed length, not being able to rotate things to minimize cable travel distance is just maddening.

It's a shame, because it's reasonably pretty. But pretty isn't enough to carry this sort of game.

* I thought this was still in Early Access! That it hasn't been for some time makes these problems even *less* understandable.

My partner and I have been playing this together, and it's such a fun time! It feels like a blend of No Man's Sky with similar elements of exploration and discovery, and Factorio/Satisfactory in the way you can create production lines for materials. We haven't even gotten into the production aspect very much yet other than setting up a couple areas of storage with auto arms to feed things like the research chamber and smelting furnace. There is also some lore to discover, and some strange buildings/artifacts scattered on the planets you'll be visiting. We spent a few hours on a joint expedition in a large rover, managing our storage space and power supply as we went. There is a nice variety of vehicles, ranging from small rovers to medium and large ones, a tractor, rockets for your backpack, a hamsterball, and a hoverboard, making simple tasks and exploration even more fun!

Most of my four hours was boring and was spent trying to figure out the inventory system which was a pain to use. Essentially you have to drag and drop the items (or full canisters of resources) to slots on the suit or the slots on the harvester then drag it from those slots any slots on the printers or other buildings, or space capsule in order to do something with those devices. 

I built a ton of tethers like 100 of them and started snaking them all over the planet because the tether is supposed to provide oxygen while you explore the world. But even with these tethers I still suffocated to death even when I was attached to them. I couldn't understand why this kept happening losing resources each time I died. The game didn't explain that you need to snap something called an oxygenator to the tethers to make oxygen. 

In the item crafting menu I eventually found the oxygenator to build, but it requires some advanced resources and structures in order to make it. I spent a good chunk of time searching for components to build the structures that were needed for the oxygenator, turns out that my starter planet didn't have those resources available. I only found out that my starter planet didn't have the resources because a screen that I somehow got to pop up that told me what the planet had. After that first time the screen popped up, I couldn't figure out how to get it to come back up.

Eventually I found out that the first Oxygenator was something you claimed from the launchpad. And I must have missed the prompts that explained that. I only realized in my last 40 minutes of play that the launchpad is where the mission come from and that you claim the completion rewards from it. I spent most of the time between starting the game and the last 40 minutes vaporizing the terrain with Terraforming tool. It was some sort of cathartic fever-pitch kind of fun until I ended up in a cave with no way back up apart from suffocating to death. When I wasn't suffocating I did have a little bit of fun.

Overall, would rate this game a strong 7 out of 10. Very polished, cozy, space-themed survival game. There are no real "enemies." Rather, plants that are stationary that present hazards to be wary of. Combat is not part of the game as a result, so the main draw is its stunning environments. They are very relaxing. 

A lot like Terraria in the sense that the beginner's experience is really confusing and there is little to no lore at face level until the VERY end of the game. After you learn the game though, it really sucks you in. 

Took me about 50 hours to full complete the game and get the achievements, but could probably be done faster. 

If you want a game to just chill out and forget about things for a while, pick this game up. If you want something more stimulating, go to Core Keeper or try ULTRAKILL!

I actually like this game a lot and wish I could give it a thumbs up, but in its current state I wouldn't recommend it, at least not for multiplayer. There's a lot of glitches, lag, and desync issues. Most of the time it's irritating but manageable, but there's one specific thing that has completely broken the game for me multiple times.

One of the most fun and useful modes of transport is to build railway systems. It lets you transport power, oxygen, and cargo long distances, as well as automate resource harvesting. But there's a severe glitch in multiplayer where all the rails will randomly vanish and pylons will no longer connect together, making your rail systems completely unusable. You can't even start over and place new rails, as they will permanently suffer from the same issue for that save file. I've lost so many hours of building and harvesting materials to this glitch.

Developers briefly acknowledged this glitch nearly a year ago when trains were first added, but since then there's been no mention of it or any efforts to fix it. Since then it seems like they've shifted their focus towards adding more stuff to the game, which I normally wouldn't complain about, but it comes with the cost of leaving this glaring issue unfixed.

If you're only interested in playing singleplayer, you can ignore everything else I've said in this review.  It'll feel a bit lonely, but otherwise you'll have a great time. The overall experience is generally very polished, and the art and sound design really nails the feeling of playing with a plastic toy set.

This game starts with a horrible onboarding experience, then if you get through it, an enjoyable play, until you'll probably rage-quit because of bugs.
But the middle part is fun.

The onboarding is really terrible, I wish the developer would stop to take feedback only from veteran players on discord and sit behind a new player for 5mn to see their first-contact experience.
You're welcomed to the game with a simple screenshot of a manual page, showing you the basic commands (WASD to move, F to interact), and then you're asked to "use the terrain tool". And then, either you close the game and launch google to find how to use a terrain tool, or you go in settings/keyboard/mapping to discover there's a E key to open the terrain tool.
It gets even worse later in the game, when you want to put train tracks, and you need to google to understand the very obscure way: put the track in the upper slot of your backpack, and use C key if it's in the upper left slot of V key if in the upper right. Of course nowhere in the game is that explained.

But once you overcome these first inconveniences and start to master the commands, the game is actually fun to play. The missions have the exact right pace, that always give you this "let's do one more task" that will make you play many more hours than you initially intended.

And then at some point you'll encounter a bug, that will cause your canister full of hard earned resources to just disappear when you travel, or you'll come back to the home planet to find that your vehicle disappeared, or you'll unboard the train to be stuck inside the wall and have to respawn and loose all your equipment.
At which point you'll probably rage-quit and stop to play ;)

So all in all, a game with lots of potential, but held down by very simple details that the developer could have fixed easily.

There's no avoiding it, it's Minecraft in space. You collect materials to craft into your base and progressively work towards a bigger base or go do the main objective as you discover it. The main difference is base components are less blocky with modular platforms, you can quickly move parts around your base for efficiency or to set up automation or just build up as you go and keep up with energy demands. Another major difference, in Minecraft the main theme is being free to mine anything and set your own objectives, you look for iron to keep your tools sharp and grind certain enemies to unlock paths to the main boss. Astroneer is all about exploring, setting a number of missions you can work on at your own pace, and makes you feel powerful with your tools. The terrain tool isn't a pickaxe but a full terraforming vacuum, it needs a few upgrades underground or to make rocky mountains easier but with a soil canister it can carry you all the way to the core of the planet. After setting a basic base it's all about meeting goals to upgrade your capabilities, field bases on other planets and finding more resources and land on increasingly hostile environments. You're free to approach challenges how you want, land on a desert planet with nothing and scavenge for resources from scratch, set up a basic base like you start with on the safe planet, or drop in with a full canister of a ton of one resource missing, a variety for anything you need in a storage silo, or a shredder + trade center to cover anything you'd be missing.
It's fun to explore, lets you set your own goals and rather than just set you against difficult goals it makes you feel powerful and just need time or some strategy.  The base building isn't very pretty but it lets you set up however you want at your own pace. I think one main problem is managing electricity and oxygen which just get tedious. Set up more solar panels to do work, more batteries for when sun and wind aren't working, more solid fuel generators to jumpstart objectives, and always need compound just for a ridiculous line of tethers while you carry half your base of batteries over. It gets a little silly how much freedom you get but I do think it's fine and lets you feel very capable, do you want to set your base close to a node to get it done quicker, build generators close by, or drop in a large rover with the generators so you can ride between all the nodes quicker and use them as fast travel?
Its great if you like a good space sandbox with a nice progression system.

7/10 - Good, chill fun with default settings. Had a great time exploring with my fiancee and discovering ways to customize vehicles and the base using the system the devs created. Obviously good enough to keep me coming back as long as I have, though I wish they had gone a bit further with some ideas (overly verbose thoughts on this below).

Really enjoyed feeling the thrill of managing oxygen in a custom game without the starting shelter, but not having the shelter throws off the quest progression (almost all quests are gated behind one that requires the shelter) in custom games which is unfortunate.

Automation was an interesting problem (kinda clunky system compared to Factorio's circuit system that I'm used to, but I eventually got something limping along), but also didn't seem particularly necessary? The neat way the printers attach their inputs is also a limiting factor on how many resources are required to make things, which means you really don't need a whole lot to complete the game. Exo Request rockets are another story, but are a tangential side quest from how the rest of the game plays.

The buggy things:
* Some multiplayer issues encountered, especially around one of us trying to use the crane on the back of a rover while the other was driving
* Camera gets wonky in tight spaces
* Paver only seems to work reliably with the large rover, often didn't actually create terrain with medium rover
* After permadeath game was converted to creative mode, fiancee could no longer join, so we had to completely abandon that save altogether.
* Flight paths of shuttles are, ehm, immersion breaking. Would be great if my shuttle doesn't fly through the core of the planet to reach its destination.

Other thoughts:
* Once we got to the large rover, the most efficient way to play was to just bring the rover, an RTG, drill, paver, and a pair of soil canisters to each planet, drive straight to the core, activate it, then move on to the next planet. In our new play-through we decided to ban that in favor of getting there on foot / train, and we're finding so many cool things that we missed on the first go around. There's so much exploration potential here, but the game gives you this nearly instant win button that is really hard to ignore.
* Paver attached to crane should be able to align to surface with control like terrain tool does normally. Kinda unusable pairing as is
* Would love a setting to disable vehicles providing unlimited oxygen
* Really wish that different amounts of fuel were required to get to other planets/moons, depending on distance and size of rocket. Carrying a huge payload with the large shuttle should consume more fuel to launch to orbit than launching a small shuttle, going to Desolo from Sylva should be easier than taking the flight to Desolo, etc. Aluminum and Ammonium are present on all planets so you're never truly stranded, but it's odd that a solid thruster is a round trip regardless of size of craft or distance to target. I think there's some interesting room for choices here. Possibly including booster segments that the shuttle can be attached to give you more single use lift to reach distant locations pre-hydrazine thrusters.

Large scale wishes:
* Wish there was a reason to care about shelters. Environmental hazards on planets like Atrox (radiation storm?), Glacio (some sort of deep freeze?), Calidus (sand storm/ heat wave?), etc that would require you to evacuate via shuttle if you don't have a shelter available, otherwise you would die. Admittedly not a huge penalty unless playing permadeath, but still. Would obviously need some sort of indicator that a storm is brewing with enough lead time to let the player escape or find their shelter.
* Wish Oxygen management were more interesting even once you get out of the early game. As it stands, oxygen becomes nearly irrelevant once you get vehicles, oxygenator, etc. The oxygenator should at least require power to function, vehicles could maybe have an internal oxygen tank to fill up similar to the astroneer's, but then adding tanks allow it to hold more for longer trips, or you could just bring along an oxygenator - but then it'll suck up power. Basically I want some interesting tradeoffs here, not just have the problem solve itself.

What can I say. It's fun, great co-op gameplay, interplanetary base-building with a fantastic soundtrack. Have played twice over and would happily start a new game. Patiently waiting for more development. The type of game that makes you search "More games like ______" once you've reached the end. I see it has its share of criticisms, and I'll admit, like basically any other game, it's not for everyone. Similar games I've played through that I would put on a relatively similar playing field would be Raft and Astro Colony, and while it is by no means a perfect game, that is an accolade that is very difficult to come by. In the end, I've thoroughly enjoyed playing Astroneer, would play it again, and if a sequel was ever released, I'd happily pay full price for it since I know the reward would be there and it would be (for me) money well spent. Highly recommended, and again, hope to see more from the devs.

I feel kinda bad for giving this a negative review, but the points I have are just too much for me to recommend this, at best this is a children's game introduction to space themed minecraft modpacks. 

-Seriously, the "space" theme here is just an idea, a minecraft modpack with dimension hopping that requires tools to merely exist without dying in said dimensions is equivalent to this game's need for oxygen. At some point I said out loud "I need a diamond armor with feather falling III"

-This is absolutely grindy as hell, I spent way too much time just preparing the preparations to make sure I had the exclusive materials of a planet to start a base on another planet so I could prepare the next planet "quests" and materials to take off to the next planet, rinse and repeat sometimes in a loop back and forth if you don't materials
-If you don't have the materials to setup the scrap trading for the materials you don't have then you are stuck unable to progress on that planet and have to grind slower to get your rocket to work again to go back to starter planet. The basic thruster only has exactly 4 uses and it takes 2 to fly+land on a different planet, so one misclick and you're stuck.
-The big points for me were actually the absurd amount of bugs, client side desync that rendered tools and objects inoperable/uninteractable/invisible. Playing multiplayer made the grind slightly less but only when we went separate ways to fulfill different chores, playing together like coop should be just makes the chores harder to manage like having to keep a storage slot occupied with a Rover Seat for the other player. And sharing mission rewards (mainly the precious small RTGs) was also incovenient at times.

-Several mission trackers were not tracking correctly depending on which player fulfilled it, at the final slug mission where you put them all together the game started the long winded cutscene, it was kinda ok but then I realized that only counted 4/7, removing and re-adding a slug caused the entire cutscene to repeat AND THERE WAS NO WAY TO SKIP IT, it locked my controls, dragged my camera and forced me to watch them "sing and dance" all over again, and it wasn't even the correct bugged slug, as I had to unplug them all and shuffle until it counted 6/7 and then I had to watch the whole thing one more time.
-This is not a one time issue, but things that affect you player state can be game breaking, when I got the third slug for the first time I arrived in a rover and left JUST AS I GOT INTO RANGE of the interaction ritual, did the emote and captured it ("Befriended it") and the cutscene that drags your camera and locks your controls absolutely made my rover stop working and even changed how the drill direction worked (I could somehow turn it with A and D without moving the rover as if it was in operation but couldn't actually drive it) which I fixed that weird limbo player state by restarting my whole game.
-One time I was trying to make plastic and got my chemical machine to somehow showed me "RESOURCE1 RESOURCE2 FUEL1" and the output was "CARBON FIBER", I could press the arrows and I could see the real items shuffling on the outside so the host had it working fine and my commands were working as intended, which meant only my own client side UI was messed up, I could select the correct craft by looking the ingredients on the hologram outside but I could not start it since I couldn't see the green button light up, re-joining fixed it..

-Trying to power the radioactive planet, the highest power requirement of all planets, I did a trick I read online about using the VTOL to winch a rover and drag it in the air, the thing physics was slapping my own ship, spinning violently, it constantly made the VTOL slow garbage speed even slower as it cancelled the straight forward speed buildup, it even somehow parked in midair once due to a collision from below. This was the only viable way to traverse the radioactive planet decently fast enough, after a most boring 40+ minutes I powered them all 6 and finally went to the core. Doing that for every planet quite sucked.
-There is a cash shop on this game for cosmetics, somehow, quite surprising, but at least the achievement base skins look decent enough to tell your friends apart from each other (after all of you played for long enough hours to deserve different looks).

-Everything in the game is janky, and you can feel the pure jank with physics, as every action you take is slippery, unwieldy, unstable, imprecise, and you think the endgame upgrades would make it better but no, the VTOL is pathetically slow, the land Rovers constantly get stuck on surface debris and terrain geometry, and that's it, every vehicle with sockets is just Rover with different things attached.
-Whoever designed this game deserves some praises at the bottom of this review but right now I want to talk about despawning debris, right, so, when you are driving a rover with a drill active for some reason it does not destroy some of the decorative physics props that become loose, they COMPLETELY PHYSICALLY BLOCK YOU AND CANNOT BE MOVED OR DESTROYED UNTIL THEY DECIDE TO DESPAWN ON THEIR OWN a few seconds later, and depending on the planet/cavern layer they can be massive or just very numerous to the point of incapacitating your ability to move with your rover until they despawn. (The biggest example in my mind is trying to make a surface path in Desolo (the moon), but there's just too many rocks...)(Removed "review too long error"). Not to mention that your caravan of connected rovers always gets stuck on the smallest thing and prevents you from backing up, you would expect them to implement something to help that but no, everything is individual physics pieces, deal with it...

-When it's not an absolute frustration this game does provide some casual chill almost mindless distraction but that is only because of the "Cracktorio" effect, which is not a positive once you realize the game is shallow and the effect has nothing to do with the game's design intention as it was just an emergent property of my own as a player, the realization of the shallowness made all my effort feel worth less than I felt building up, 
-What drove me to play so much was the initial feelings of exploration and wonder coupled with the expectation of a factory game with a space exploration theme, but what I got was a repetitive inventory management hell. 
-At this point I only play to be a company to my friend easing his experience and preparing stuff for them, and a sunken costs of trying to finish the solo playthrough just to get to the end, as I feel "morally obligated to finish the game to give a 'proper' review", my friend quite liked the game though but somehow only wants to play when I am available, I wonder why /s.

+The socket system feels great design, everything is visually represented in sockets, good sounds for picking and placing things in sockets, it's awesome, but
-There are no hotkeys for inventory management, you have to click and click FOR EACH ITEM you want to move, every single time, there is no easy way to dump your inventory anywhere, shift clicking only takes TO your backpack, 
-And the snapping sometimes goes freaking bonkers all over the place EXCEPT the very top socket you are mouse over, you need pixel perfect precision sometimes, for example when having a slug in your backpack with a seed on top, you can't easily move the slug without taking the seed instead, you have to carefully pixel by pixel move the mouse to the edge where it raycasts to the hitbox of the slug AND THEN you can pick up the slug terrarium.

+(Deleted, "review too long error")
-Sometimes I wish a machine wouldn't just swallow an item automatically and hold on to it like a cat biting a bag of bread meme but it isn't  a problem most of the time, the only one I got mad was a research lab automatically bitten and was eating my ingots twice when I was shuffling medium storages around...

Astroneer is a beautiful open world sandbox game taking place in star system.
Mechanics aren't awfully complex and it's approachable by almost anyone.

You don't lack any capabilities and this game also has a very exciting lore behind it.
You can build buggies, trucks, trains, jetpacks and later even obtain a VTOL aircraft.

This game has grown in the past years and amazing content was added to it.

I would recommend anyone to give it a shot as it's unbelieveably addicting.
There always is a sense of exploration and the unknown, being able to visit every planet in this star system to gather new resources just adds to that.

There are no enemies besides some hostile plants which you can defeat by digging them up with your tool.
Other than that you only may die due to suffocation, fall damage or said plants.

If you like Chores, this is the game for you! 
The only "fun" you will probably have is with the Earth-Gun which has no limit in digging and you can make some funny figures with it, that is all the fun. 
The principal is this, you dig for something 
- find that something 
- find more than you need and your finite (and not extendable) inventory space will allow you to carry (literally like 8-9 stacks max) 
- use the ones you need and just let the rest lay around to rot (the storage system is practically non-existent, and if, it is the most tedious system, mostly drag and drop) 
- then you get to the top, notice you are missing a specific resource 
- get back down, repeat. 
The only difference that can occur is that the crucial resource you need is on another planet, so you can do the same thing as above but instead of digging you sit in a spacecraft that is one miss-click away from ruining the whole game.

The crafting is boring as hell, because you don´t, you get printers which can print the needed things, this seems logical until you have so much useless stuff you simply do not need anymore to craft in the hud system and you can then sift through all of them for the desired one. 

The camera movement and placement need you to stay calm at times, because they simply don´t want to work, you will often have to twist the camera to simply load stuff onto something or worse you want to "quickly" get your fallen backpack so you can continue were you left. 
The biggest enemy is the oxygen, it is not challenging but a chore again, you will have to bring "tethers" which connect you to your oxygen, they take up a whole space in your bag and they get annoying quick. 
the camera/viewing mechanic is simply just there because they wanted to be different, allowing a 1st person view would already greatly improve the game.

For space exploration fans like myself, ASTRONEER is a dream come true. I can spend hours zenning out as I discover new surprises. I’ve never played another game that matches this one's sense of adventure. ASTRONEER is an absolute treasure.

In ASTRONEER, each planet presents new challenges to overcome. Gather resources to craft tools, vehicles, and bases. Play solo or join friends to create sprawling communities. But the core of the experience is pure exploration - let your childlike curiosity loose to uncover the mysteries scattered across vivid alien worlds.

A casual, relaxing combination of satisfactory and Dyson sphere program, though it does lack the depth and scale of the aforementioned games. 
Things I liked: 
Fully destructible and shape-able voxel environment.
Religiously 3D items, everything is rendered and has physics.
Insanely stable, the game never crashed, and the ever present physics system never freaked out.
Great audio, most of it sounds like foley with a satisfying feel.

Things I didn't: 
The menus for crafting and unlocking buildings/items are poorly made. 
Endgame and advanced factory setups are entirely optional, whole game can be completed with a couple of each building. 
The way you travel between planets (rocket) felt underdeveloped. 

Overall a great casual exploration/base building game, cozy and great with friends.

I bought this game when it was on sale, and I have honestly had a blast with it. I had seen this game before, and was skeptic to buy it, because I did not know if there would be enough content to make it worth while. Boy was I wrong! This game's simple but detailed system will have you micromanaging your base, completing quests, and exploring the different randomly generated worlds. I was amazed how much there was and still is to do in the game. I would conclude that it is worth giving it a play.

To start my review I just wanna say, this game is a perfect gift or game to buy for anyone looking for a relaxing game

To begin, we have the music, I think its one of the best parts of the game, it doesn't seem to play often, mostly because its action based (for the most part) but there's just something about the music, when it plays, how its made, and the setting, it all just fits together in such a perfect way. I would say I could never cry and to a soundtrack, but something about knowing this game for such a long time, being able to watch what comes out of it and see the growth, and the strength of the community, and the simple beauty of walking around the planet with such a pretty soundtrack coming through my headphones just makes me so happy and feel something else that no game I've ever played can make me think

The second reason is, the gameplay (Grinding) is something else, this game has lots to do. Sure! Go out and get minerals from the depths of the planet or find some stuff from the surface OR spend some time and automate it, speaking of as well, the automation update made everything in the game feel this much bit better than it was before. You get to choose how you wanna play the game, slow, fast, long, and now you can even make a challenge for yourself!

-Spoilers- (But also facts)

And lastly, the *ascetic* and features. The game just all fits together from the lore to the cool things you find, you could go from being on the surface just getting some resources like resin or compound, then stumble upon what you could only think is a weird purple thing, then you realize you can go to different planets! Now you found that, you try digging down a bit further than before "Oh, theres a whole new biome and stuff down here!" Dig further and you find the core... Leave the planet and Oh? theres a 'mysterious satellite' above the sun and hell why not be able to go into the sun, and you can! Its just so charming

I know I said lastly in my last reason, but this isn't a reason, its a thanks. From all the insperations, motivation, and all those other goofy times, whether its the cute little creatures you find or the minerals you mine. From the depths of my heart and soul, I want to thank all the comfort I have felt from playing Astroneer, its something no other game can do.

:) (Yes I was listening to the soundtrack while writing lol)

This may be the single best video game I've ever played. If you like games like Minecraft, you will enjoy this game, but do not expect it to be similar to Minecraft. It focuses much more on exploration and is less of a sandbox game, although there are sandbox elements. The game allows you to take your play at your own pace. Whether you want to explore different planets first or build up your home base - either way, you'll have a fantastic, and unique, adventure. The poly art style is very cute, and the soundtrack is very mysterious and foreboding, immersing you in the adventure of the game very well. While I wish the game tied more into the lore that certain mysterious objects provide, I'm almost glad they don't since it makes the game seem more open-world.

Great crafting/mining game.  Perfect balance of research, grind, explore, craft.  Doesn't progress too quickly or slowly.  Keeps you engaged and enjoying for a long time.

Disappointing.

I have owned it since 2018 and the game has gone backwards. All of the meaningful features were created back then, and nothing good has been added since.

There are no enemies or environmental hazards at all. There used to be storms like No Man's Sky, but they were removed. They used to blow loose resources around unless you had them in proper storage.

They have increased the grind by increasing the amount of resources, and putting them on different planets.

They have added features like trains and automation, but this isn't Dyson Sphere Program, or Factorio, so I don't know why you would ever need them. It's just pointless. You don't need that many resources for anything, and research points are all over the surface now, so no need to even go underground.

Keyboard/mouse controls have been sacrificed in favour of gamepad. Lots of "Hold F" to do anything instead of clicking an in-world button like before.

They won't add anything to the game that negatively affects Nintendo Switch performance.
If you need something to completely chill out and vibe with either solo or with friends, this game is exactly that, play it your way and enjoy life

The joy of setting up your colony, from constructing basic habitats to research labs, is fun. However, I feel the game could definitely benefit from more platform choices, adding that extra bit of versatility. Yet, this minor limitation doesn't overshadow the positive adventure.

i first come across astroneer in early access watching a dev VLOG on youtube, i decided to buy the game as the game seemed to have alot of potential the devs seemed really friendly and was focused on building the game from community suggestions, 

after joining the discord i soon realized the devs are incredibly friendly often reaching out to user about bugs and suggestions, 
after posting some cool screenshots in the discord the devs reached out and gave me early access to creative mode, and here i was thinking only proper content creators would get that kind of treatment. i am now moderator on the discord. 

a few years later, the game has come a long way and the devs have delivered, the game still gets updates and they are driven by community suggestions

as long as you don't expect a perfect game with no bugs you should really enjoy astroneer as it does have its fair share of bugs, each update seems to break something in game and fix the previous thing that broke,

I really liked this game, the issue is that I bought it to play multiplayer and there are a list of issues I could go over for that. If you're playing by yourself, go for it, but don't get this to play MP.

The game doesn't allow you to host a world locally without running the server in a separate window and port forwarding... Is this not 2023? This is some playing minecraft in 2012 stuff...

Not only does it not allow you to do that, the server itself even when hosted off a 3rd party dedicated server platform is unstable and needs to be restarted once every 1-2 hours in order to stop vehicles from just glitching into the center of the planet when you try to get in it...

I've spent maybe half of my game time just re-doing things that were lost because for some reason the server decided to not save, or the autosave interval was 5 minutes before one of our vehicles flew into the stratosphere and disappeared.

Its just insane that I can't fire up a world and have my friends join me off steam in a game thats been out this long. MP was a clear afterthought, and I'm sure people are going to say "oh well it wasnt intended to be a MP game" well, then dont release a half-baked version of MP...

I've played this game from when it first launched on xbox (if I remember correctly I don't think they even had vehicles back then or if they were they were very buggy), and now seeing how the game has grown over the years is amazing. The game has a wonderful soundtrack, and maybe it's just me, but these visuals they have created with this game are amazing, but they may not be for everyone. I've never gotten far progression wise, even after playing the game for how long I have, but I still find it fun making progress even if it ends up with me creating a new world to start from scratch with. I can't even imagine how many I have with my xbox hours I've built up. When I was thinking of purchasing this game on steam I thought it was a hard buy for the price point and I thought I've already seen everything there is no way they added anything else, but I was surprised to what I came back to, and I was surprised by how many hours I've already put into again, and I don't really intend to stop my play through right now, so I can only see me playing more of this game!

I really wanted to like this game.  I was hoping I would like it better after playing it for several hours.  I think it could still be fun but I would have to really study a lot about how it works.  I think there are some things that are really lacking in the game design.  For example, I just got the medium printer going.  I had no idea how to use it.  I've been trying for about 3 days to figure it out.  Finally, I figured out a phrase to Google asking how to look up items the medium printer could make and choose one.  Finally, I found a post which said that you have to hold down "F" to see the choices.  That was MUCH too hard to figure out.  There were a lot of aspects of the game like that.  i might still play it.  Maybe in the creative mode.  I was really more interested in the game for the exploration aspect of it.  I don't want to have to struggle so much with it.  The game designers definitely could have made all this clearer.  I think a tutorial mode which shows you how all of these things work would be helpfu.

Game is fun UNTIL YOU DIE, at which point it becomes incredibly tedious.

You will be out exploring in your vehicle, as you do, and eventually you'll run over a random invisible crack in the ground, at which point your vehicle will tumble into the depths, and you'll pop out of it and die.

Now, you respawn at your base with NOTHING. No vehicle. No tethers, nothing. Your vehicle is halfway across the world along with everything you need to get back to it, so you get to essentially restart the game by collecting the resources to build another vehicle so that you can.... go and get your vehicle... and then you have TWO! One of which is a total waste, and by this time you've sunk at least an hour into the most frustrating slog in the world because you can't just get to your old vehicle. No no, you now have to tunnel down to it, but you can't because all your tunneling digging mods are on your corpse... so you have to build a bunch of mods and tethers just so that you can begin hunting for your vehicle.. but getting to it isn't enough because it fell through an invisble crack it's now several hundred feet in the ground, AND THE ONLY WAY TO GET IT BACK IS TO MANUALLY BUILD A RAMP THAT LEADS ALL THE WAY BACK TO THE SURFACE!!!!!! fffffffffffffffff You guys are literally torturing us.

Prepare to embark on an interplanetary journey filled with wonder, laughter, and plenty of 'launch' puns! Astroneer is an absolute blast (off) of a game that catapults you into a sandbox adventure like no other.

From the moment you crash-land on a colorful and alien planet, you'll find yourself digging, building, and exploring with childlike enthusiasm. The game's beautiful art style is like a breath of fresh oxygen in space, captivating your imagination as you uncover the secrets of the cosmos.

The gameplay mechanics are as smooth as a zero-gravity float, allowing you to shape the terrain and uncover valuable resources. However, there are moments when the controls can feel a bit clunky, especially during precision placement of objects or maneuvering complex machinery. A little fine-tuning in this area would make the experience even more enjoyable.

You'll dig through caverns, searching for those sweet, sweet bytes to unlock new technologies. It's like being a space-faring Indiana Jones, except with fewer boulders and more adorable space rovers! However, the progression system could benefit from more clarity and guidance, as it can be overwhelming for new players to understand the optimal path forward.

Speaking of rovers, you'll have a blast constructing vehicles to traverse the treacherous terrain. It's like being a futuristic stunt driver, performing flips and tricks across the craters. Just don't forget your space seatbelt—safety first, even in the vastness of the galaxy! However, the vehicle physics can be a bit wonky at times, leading to unexpected flips or getting stuck in the landscape. A touch of refinement in this area would greatly enhance the driving experience.

But Astroneer is not just a solo adventure; it's a cosmic party waiting to happen. Grab your friends and embark on cooperative missions together. There's nothing like laughing together as you accidentally launch each other into orbit or get tangled in a mess of tethers. However, the multiplayer experience can suffer from occasional lag and synchronization issues, impacting the overall enjoyment. Some dedicated attention to optimizing the netcode would make the cooperative play even more seamless and immersive.

In conclusion, Astroneer is a stellar experience that catapults you into a world of adventure, friendship, and laughs. It's like a moonlit picnic with a side of interplanetary exploration. While it has a few rough edges that could benefit from some polish, the overall experience is still immensely enjoyable. So buckle up, grab your jetpack, and get ready to reach for the stars!

Rating: ★★★★☆
Astroneer is a launchpad of joy and hilarity that will keep you entertained for light-years to come. With a bit of refinement in certain areas, it has the potential to become an intergalactic masterpiece."

Astroneer: A Relaxing Game with Hidden Depths

Astroneer is a wonderfully tranquil game that offers simple mechanics while still presenting enough complexity to keep players engaged. Its development tree is impressively deep, providing a stimulating sense of progression. Despite the absence of NPCs, stories, guests, or enemies, there is always something to do.

The user interface can be a bit frustrating initially, but once you get used to it, it proves to be practical. One notable drawback, however, is the difficulty in smoothing the terrain. It would greatly benefit from a tool or mode that allows for the construction of floors with different colors and textures, aligning seamlessly with the planet's curvature.

One of the game's strengths lies in its diverse range of planets, each offering unique challenges. Occasionally, more helpful information or guidance regarding specific objects or machines on these planets would be appreciated.

Adding a touch of lore to the experience could further enhance the game. While the absence of traditional storytelling elements is intentional, a bit of background narrative would add depth and immersion.

The game's assortment of vehicles greatly contributes to its overall entertainment value. Similarly to the terrain, having the ability to construct pathway blocks that conform to the planet's circumference would be a welcome addition.

TL/DR: Astroneer is a relaxing game with simple mechanics that still manage to provide a satisfying challenge. Although lacking NPCs, stories, guests, or enemies, it remains engaging with a deep development tree. The user interface can be frustrating, particularly when trying to smooth the terrain. More assistance and lore would enhance the gameplay. The variety of planets and vehicles keeps the experience enjoyable. Overall, Astroneer offers a tranquil yet stimulating gaming experience.

Astroneer is a very calming but engaging experience, complete with excellent sound design and amazing scenery to look at. The games soundtrack is also incredible, as is the control scheme. Overall this is a very polished game with so much content and "re-playability" which the developers clearly love and put an incredible amount of effort into.
If you're looking for a casual game which you can play with friends, (if you feel like it) then this game is easily a 10/10 and well worth putting some time into.

This is a really fun exploration/base building game. It is very relaxing as well. I enjoy the fact that you need to search out and mine minerals needed to create new blueprints and the progress of the game feels like is has really nice pace to it. Some planets are quite easy to develop on while other planets give you more of a challenge. Though this game is fun, it is twice as fun playing with friends. It is a great multi-player game to chill with friends.

Astroneer is quite a unique game with nice eastetics and a few good concepts.

But it's also very tedious.

Every task involves so many steps and fiddling around that it felt like chores. It almost appears that the game was designed to make most basic tasks as hard as possible for the player. Each progression step will only give the player a possibility to make it just a [i]tiiiny[/i] bit easier, while introducing new hurdles at the same time.
Then there are literal setbacks, e.g. when you're forced to travel to a different planet for obtaining a new resource and start a new base from scratch. With the tier 1 rocket it isn't even possible to attach any built machines or even travel with a coop buddy. And the limited fuel (which requires resources to craft) pretty much eliminates the option to make multiple trips back and forth.
While the UI is very beautiful and immersive/consistent, it is extremely cumbersome. Finding a specific machine inside the four different printer categories and indistinguishable sub-categories is pure torture. Why they haven't even designed different category icons (like "Power", "Vehicles", "Storage", etc.) is beyond me. Every sub-category is just a generic dot with no label or tool tip.

The final nail in the coffin for me was when I figured out how limited automation is in Astroneer. For the longest time I thought that eventually I'll be able to eliminate most of the tedious tasks, like constantly searching and collecting natural resources, by building automated factories. After failing to figure it out I looked up some automation guides on YouTube and was disappointed how even the jankyiest automation builds still required some manual input (like collecting soil for the Soil Centrifuge).

I could go on an on with these minor annoyances: Small inventory sizes, lack of proper resource storage, fiddly building, long printing times, machines requiring additional base platforms for placement, no UI to see power consumption/generation...

Most of these can't even be considered design flaws (except the UI sub-categories), as they all follow this consistent concept, which is probably what the game is all about. It's just not for me.

If you like to spend dozens of hours farming resources in beautiful, calming environments and slowly build up bases piece by piece, this game might be for you, though.

Great little game to play with friends. Super relaxing (in most cases), and death is usually caused by you accidentally deleted the wrong terrain and now you're out of reach from your tethers with no easy way to get back. Lots to learn, build, and make your own.

Only downside for me is the way the game saves. Every single time someone enters a vehicle, the game saves, which causes a second or two lag to try and save the game. Had a few other things happen like your death marker disappearing if someone else dies, the backpack just being massive and not going away until I restarted, and the controls take a bit to get used to. 

Overall it was a fun experience to 100%

After my first full play through of this game, I would say that I really enjoy the immersive environment and I would agree that this can be a calm, relaxing game as much as it can be a frustrating, stressful game. The missions are easy to follow but tedious at times and the story is entertaining enough to hold interest. The terraforming mechanics have the potential to hold a creative individuals attention for quite awhile. I also like how there are different color palettes and cosmetic items you can unlock by just playing the game. The game has some physics issues when it comes to flying to each planet, which breaks the immersion just a little bit but the game is visually appealing and this issue can be overlooked easily. The Co-op part of this game is engaging and fun since you can both carry/gather more resources and vehicle/shuttles can be made to carry multiple people. I would recommend playing this game if you need a chill space survival base builder, you might also enjoy Scrap Mechanic.

Astroneer is an absolute gem of a game that takes you on a thrilling interstellar adventure, combining exploration, creativity, and resource management into a captivating experience. As an ardent gamer, I've had the pleasure of diving into countless virtual worlds, but Astroneer manages to stand out among the rest with its unique blend of stunning visuals, immersive gameplay, and boundless possibilities.

One of the first things that struck me about Astroneer is its breathtaking art style. The game's vibrant, low-poly aesthetic creates a whimsical atmosphere that feels simultaneously otherworldly and inviting. Every planet and celestial body you encounter is a visual feast, with a remarkable attention to detail that makes you want to explore every nook and cranny.

Exploration lies at the heart of Astroneer, and it's an absolute joy to traverse the diverse landscapes, uncover hidden mysteries, and unearth precious resources. From vast desert terrains to eerie underground caverns and even the vast expanse of space, each location is filled with surprises and challenges waiting to be conquered. The sense of discovery is truly enthralling, as you never know what wonders or obstacles lie just beyond the horizon.

The game's emphasis on creativity is truly commendable. Astroneer offers an impressive array of tools and gadgets that allow you to reshape the environment to your liking. Sculpting the terrain, building intricate structures, and setting up sprawling bases becomes an addictive form of expression. The sheer satisfaction of transforming a barren landscape into a thriving outpost is incredibly rewarding, and it fuels your desire to push further and unravel more of the game's mysteries.

Astroneer's cooperative multiplayer mode adds an extra layer of excitement and teamwork to the experience. Collaborating with friends to explore distant planets, coordinate resource gathering, and construct ambitious projects amplifies the game's sense of camaraderie. The shared journey becomes an unforgettable bonding experience as you conquer challenges together and celebrate each triumph.

What truly sets Astroneer apart is its sense of wonder and limitless potential. Whether you're constructing intricate machinery, establishing interplanetary transportation networks, or unraveling the secrets of the universe, the game constantly pushes your boundaries and encourages your imagination to soar. It beautifully captures the essence of space exploration and leaves you in awe of the vastness and mystery that lies beyond our Earthly confines.

In conclusion, Astroneer is a remarkable game that excels in every aspect it sets out to conquer. Its mesmerizing visuals, captivating gameplay, and unbounded creativity make it a true standout among its peers. If you're a fan of exploration, resource management, and the wonders of space, Astroneer is an absolute must-play. Prepare to embark on an extraordinary astral journey that will leave you enchanted and longing for more.

Pros: Solid game, can run on a wide variety of machines. Most space exploration games are gritty and dark (nothing wrong with that, just not my preference), but this has bright colors and cute slugs, making it more appealing to a wider audience. I’ve played since Early Access—the game hasn’t changed a lot, but it was already good at its core. Cave system is easily a 10/10.

Cons: More fun as co-op than single player.  Certain tasks require special tools and an excessive amount of time—this, as well as certain controls, have to be explained by another player (which somewhat undermines the broad appeal). The tutorial could use a lot of improvement.

Amazing game! A blend of base building, exploration and gradual progression. Super relaxing and easy going. It’s an open sandbox where you can do whatever you want in whichever order you like. Just take your time and enjoy the process.

The best part of it is just figuring out how it all works – what the objective is, the core gameplay loop, how all the items and modules work and interact with each other. There is a nice sense of progression all throughout, you are continuously getting better items that keep improving your quality of life. If you enjoy base building and organization, there is plenty of that to be had, and even some satisfying automation. 

The game is best played in co-op. Sure you can play it solo, but part of the fun is just experiencing everything with some friends. Good times guaranteed!

I’m 45 years old and I have never had a good relationship with my dad. We barely talked and we had nothing in common. He was always busy with work and I felt like he didn’t care about me. I grew up resenting him and avoiding him as much as possible.

But then I discovered this game. I decided to give it a try and invited my dad to play with me. He was hesitant at first, but he agreed to give it a chance.

We started playing and something amazing happened. We started talking. We started laughing. We started bonding. We learned more about each other and we realized that we had more in common than we thought. We shared our stories, our dreams, our fears, our hopes. We became friends!

We played the game every night for a month. We completed the main story and all the side quests. We explored every corner of the game world and we enjoyed every moment of it. We had fun.

My dad got sick and he passed away. It was sudden and unexpected. It broke my heart.

But I’m grateful for the game. It gave me the opportunity to reconnect with my dad before he left. It gave me the chance to say goodbye and to tell him that I love him. It gave me the best memories of my life.

This game is more than just a game. It’s a gift. It’s a miracle. It’s a masterpiece.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants to have a meaningful and emotional experience with someone they love.

Thank you, developers, for creating this game.

Thank you, dad, for playing with me.

I miss you so much...

I really enjoy this game. It scratches an itch I never knew I had.

Everything in the game has a sort of feedback to it. Every step has some sort of animation or sound or SFX that really makes you feel like you are involved in what is happening. It all feels very satisfying.

The voxel digging is smooth and leads to really cool building (once, built a sky-bridge completely around the equator of a planet). You'll probably smile when you learn you can slide for the first time, and then realize you can build a huge ramp for a fun time.
The game really expands from there. Every step in the game leads to another step and another goal, which is amazingly well puzzled together.

As you get further in the game and start to unravel the mysteries, you really start to experiment and try new things. More often than not, you are validated with a success.

The major updates since 1.0 have only made the game better. Missions and creatures are amazing and really help fill up any minor empty space in the progression. Also, the new compass was the greatest thing to ever happen to this game!

My only gripe is the UI is a little hard for people to learn for the first time. However, once you have played for any amount of time, it does start to become second nature, and makes a lot of sense.

What a gem this game is, goodness I wish more people knew about it. 

There is something so immensely satisfying with how tactile everything is. Everything sorta clicks and pops together, whether it's plugging in the power cord to a something, or attaching a module to a platform. Even inventory kinda works similar to this with items you find out in the wild. It's something you have to see for yourself, but it's just so damn satisfying. 

The art design... what can I say.... It's some of the finest work I've ever seen in gaming. Simple yet, jaw droppingly gorgeous. I gotta give homage to the original art designer Paul Pepera, may he rest in peace and his beautiful imagination be immortalized within this game. 

This game has something for everyone really. From exploring and navigating dangerous environments. to building your base and maintaining your resources. Building and driving wild exocraft, or shooting off into the stars to explore a new planet. 

I could ramble on and on about the game but honestly you should see it for yourself. Do it now! Play the game!!

Astroneer is a delightful journey through the cosmos that keeps players mesmerized from start to finish. The game's stunning visuals and vibrant art style bring the alien worlds to life, immersing players in a universe filled with wonder and discovery. The freedom to explore vast landscapes, uncover hidden mysteries, and craft intricate structures provides boundless possibilities for creative experimentation. With a rewarding progression system that allows players to unlock new technologies and expand their capabilities, Astroneer delivers a sense of growth and accomplishment. The cooperative multiplayer feature adds an extra layer of enjoyment, allowing friends or even strangers to team up and explore the cosmos together, creating memorable moments of shared discovery. Astroneer's regular updates and commitment to the community ensure that the game remains fresh, engaging, and continuously captivating.

There are very few titles that manage to encapsulate the sheer wonder and exploration inherent in space adventure quite like Astroneer. Having spent 117 hours navigating through the different celestial bodies and innovating within the vast sandbox it provides, I can wholeheartedly recommend Astroneer as a must-play for any fan of exploration, survival, and sandbox games.

Astroneer plunges you into a vibrant and richly hued universe filled with distinctive planets to explore and mysteries to unravel. The serene yet captivating beauty of these procedurally generated environments makes the exploration experience truly immersive and awe-inspiring. From the green plains of Sylva to the desolate landscapes of Desolo, each planet holds its own charm and unique set of resources and hazards.

The core mechanic in Astroneer revolves around terraforming - the ability to alter the environment by digging, elevating, or flattening terrain. This mechanic is not just a tool but an integral part of gameplay, allowing you to shape your surroundings to your will, whether you're digging for resources, building a base, or sculpting a mountain just for the sake of it. This mechanic is incredibly satisfying and grants players an enormous amount of freedom in interacting with the world.

Resource gathering and crafting play a central role in Astroneer. Resources are plentiful, yet are spread out and often hidden beneath the surface, prompting you to venture out, explore, and extract. The game's crafting system is both intuitive and expansive, encouraging you to progress by building increasingly complex items and structures. This progression system, though not explicitly defined, guides you naturally towards expansion and technological advancement.

Base building in Astroneer is an exceptionally rewarding experience. There's a wonderful sense of accomplishment that comes from transforming a small landing pad into a sprawling, resource-processing, research-generating facility. The ability to design and organize your base layout as you please adds an additional layer of personal touch to the game.

One of Astroneer’s strengths lies in its multiplayer functionality. Teaming up with friends to tackle projects or explore uncharted territories adds a new layer of fun and camaraderie to the experience. Cooperation becomes key, turning complex tasks into fun, group activities.

The game's art style is refreshingly unique - a beautiful blend of stylized visuals and vibrant, saturated colors. This, combined with the serene, ambient music and satisfying sound effects, creates a whimsical atmosphere that still feels intrinsically sci-fi.

The controls and interface of Astroneer deserve praise for their simplicity and ease of use. However, like many sandbox games, Astroneer has a learning curve at the beginning, but once mastered, the controls feel intuitive and responsive.

On the downside, there can be occasional performance issues, especially when exploring large, complex caverns or running a heavily developed base. However, these are relatively infrequent and, given the game's many strong points, are minor drawbacks.

Astroneer is a game about exploration and creativity. It doesn't rush you with timers or overwhelm you with threats. Instead, it gives you a set of tools and systems, and then sets you free in a universe filled with possibilities. For its rewarding exploration, its unique and satisfying terraforming mechanics, its vibrant and relaxing atmosphere, and its well-executed multiplayer mode, Astroneer is a truly exceptional game that I highly recommend to other players.

I bought this game some years ago because it was space-themed and on sale. After a few minutes of trying it and learning how to navigate the gameplay, it was clear I'd got a major deal buying it.

This is one of my favorite building games because unlike every other building game, it doesn't really have any "grind" to it.

You have a tech tree you need to advance up, and exploration you need to do, but you generally don't need to mass produce anything.  Your bases usually end up with one or two of each building type, with the one exception being storage but storage buildings are relatively cheap to construct.

This is in notable contrast to most building games where advancing through the game usually means producing many orders of magnitude more resources, and often without significantly better tools to do so.  You are often (in other games) expected to just grind out 40,000 harvesting buildings, or production buildings, etc.

EDIT: Was a kid when I reviewed this game here is something more appropriate.

Back in the day (Around 2016 or 2017) This game was released onto steam for early access. Although there was not much to do in terms of progression and story. The game was certainly interesting because of how it created a unique system of exploration and crafting in a simple form. 

The game now is fully released and is still be updated with new features. Obviously at a slower pace than what it used to be. There's plenty to do and theirs now a story to follow. Over the years of changes the game is a bit more complex yet still manages to keep its simplicity over the years. There's finally a goal within the game and there's so much more to do. the game focuses more on survival within the planets themselves. Each planet having unique resources and different gases from one another. Some may have the same while others would be unique. Exploration is a key component in the game rather than focusing on survival. if you like environments and easy going game play as well as just the game being Sci-Fi then this might be an easy grab for you. how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
½ teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

Astroneer is an ambitious and visually stunning exploration game that takes players on an interplanetary journey filled with wonder and discovery. Its unique art style and immersive gameplay mechanics offer a refreshing experience, although a few minor drawbacks prevent it from reaching its full potential.

One of the standout aspects of Astroneer is its breathtaking visual design. The colorful and vibrant landscapes of various planets are a treat for the eyes, and the attention to detail in the environmental design is impressive. The game's art style strikes a perfect balance between simplicity and depth, creating an otherworldly atmosphere that draws players into its vast, uncharted universe.

The core gameplay mechanics in Astroneer are engaging and offer a sense of freedom and creativity. The ability to shape the terrain, gather resources, and build intricate structures fuels the spirit of exploration and provides a satisfying sense of accomplishment. The inclusion of cooperative multiplayer further enhances the experience, allowing friends to collaborate and tackle the challenges together.

However, Astroneer does have a few minor hiccups that can occasionally detract from the overall enjoyment. One such issue is the occasional lack of guidance or clear objectives. While the game encourages exploration and discovery, some players may find themselves unsure of what to do or where to go next, leading to moments of confusion or aimlessness. A more structured progression system or additional in-game hints could help alleviate this potential frustration.

Another aspect that could benefit from improvement is the game's performance and optimization. While Astroneer runs smoothly for the most part, there are instances where frame rate drops or occasional glitches can momentarily disrupt the immersion. While these occurrences are infrequent and don't significantly impact the overall experience, they are noticeable enough to warrant mention.

Despite these minor shortcomings, Astroneer remains a captivating adventure that offers a unique and immersive gameplay experience. Its stunning visuals, open-ended exploration, and cooperative multiplayer make it an excellent choice for those seeking a tranquil and creative journey through the cosmos. With continued updates and refinements, Astroneer has the potential to become an even more remarkable and polished experience in the future.

I wasn't expecting to enjoy this game as much as I have been, but I'm 35 hours in and still going strong. The quest system does a great job walking you through some of the basics, while still giving you a lot of flexibility to go off and do whatever you want. It has a great progression from simple crafting to more advanced resource management that you can develop gradually at first, but then jump through much more quickly later in the game when setting up new outposts. Trains are a lot of fun. I'm looking forward to getting into some of the more advanced power and resource management functions, but I'm taking it slow and just enjoying the process right now.
